Nice place. Old and as expected. The prices in Old town is over the top but i expected that too :) Much People there on daytime. Tips: Come very early on the morning or very late at night
Is that a clock?. A gothic town centre with a baroque overlay through twisting, dog-leg street of cobble stone (do not wear high heels) lined with tourist shops. Great fun.

One of the nicest historical heritages in Europe. Stare Mesto is a place where you are willing to go, to return and to return again, with its nices small roads (somewhere too touristic, but unfortunately it happens everywhere), the nice local restaurants and shops and the breathtaking old time square, with the famous astronomic clock, the town hall, the St. Mary over Tyn church and all the surrounding buildings. Everything seems to be at the right place, and even if it is always crowded you never fell "trapped".
Great City. Travelled in Jan, 2013. Beautiful architecture, every turn was a feast for the senses. Thoroughly enjoyed getting lost in the city.
The Old streets. it's a very famous...and interesting walking.....in that old streets.... The homeless people's its very strange in here....and the TOWN is.....perfekt for a nice sightseeing.
Beautiful. Touristy.. Great place to check out. Like the other posts, many tourists. Crowded, beware of pickpockets, they CAN be numerous.
Beautiful. This is a VERY touristy area, so be careful with you bags/purses, etc. There is a free restroom in the Starbucks!
Busy area of Prague. This area is a busy area in Prague. There are many stores and restaurants. This is an area with many tourists which make it loud.Still if offers many choices for tourists.
Too crowded to enjoy. its a noisy mess. Too crowded to enjoy. The whole charm gets lost very quickly. Though the buildings are colorful as everyone notes, when we went it was just a zoo.

Very touristy, but worth the trip. Prague Old Town is simply gorgeous and well worth a trip. History and gorgeous buildings everywhere and very walkable. Not too easy for those of us who are internal compass impaired, so bring your map. On the downside, because of the touristy nature of the old town, there were very many people constantly competing for our attention or to sell us something. It was a little unnerving to be bombarded by street vendors constantly when one does not speak the language. At night, this became scary at times, but generally felt pretty safe.

Interesting. Lots of shops and cafes. The one thing that everyone waits for is at the top of the hour at the astronomical clock two little doors open so you can see the apostles. Not all that exciting, but if you happen to swing by within five minutes I would stay and watch it.

One of my favourite places in the world. Prague, as a whole, is a stunningly beautiful city. It's one of those places that you say "you have to go there before you die."The first time I went in 2012, I was with 3 friends and old town square is the place we was at a lot of the time.I went again on my own last year and I got to see so much more that this fantastic place offers. There is always so much going on, and you will never get bored.Do yourself a favour, and travel to Prague and while you're there, visit the beautiful Old Town!

Disabled review of Prague. I knew that Prague would be difficult due to the cobbles, but what I really struggled with was that roads and paths are just not maintained well enough. Cobbles were missing everywhere meaning that there were holes to weave around, and this was in the newer area where the 'cobbles' were 5x5cm stone blocks placed in a decorative pattern not the big cobbles that we found in Old Town. We rarely found a dropped curb and if we did, there might not have been one on the other side, so we weaved our way through the beautiful city of Prague in the rain.

What a place !. If You never been to Prague Before - this is what You must look for.You can just walk around there for hours just to look at the old houses and churches. I Think I can spend several Days down in the old Town and the streets around the Square all the way down to Charles Bridge that is only 500- 800 meters from there.
Prague Old Town Enchanting <3. so charming and beautiful, a jewel in Prague's crown, Astronomical clock, go up the tower for wonderful views of the city and castle. Truly beautiful.

Every one needs to go to old town. Old town is where every thing is happening. History is told by the various architecture that surround you 360 degrees. Every nationality is representative. The major statues are in the center of the plaza. Pick pockets abound...hold on to your wallet...I think inside the bra is the best place to hold cash. For men... Be creative

Love Old Town. We have visited Prague twice, love Old Town and the shopping. Both times I shopped Blue for gifts, all products in the store are made in Czech Republic which is important. I like to support the local people where I visit.

A place with almost no ugliness. The Old Town I would describe as the place with unnoticed ugliness. I and my wife spent some time there during our visit to Prague. Although it was crowded with tourists from many countries still we felt the nice atmosphere.You can find souvenirs shops, places to enjoy the time, food vendors, and a lot of touristy things while seeing old buildings. Such a perfect mixture!Perhaps the most important attraction there is the Astronomical Clock. From the tower you can see the bird view of Prague.If you need touristy information, you can find it easily there as there is such information center. You can ask things even suggestions and you will get clear answers.All I would say is that you should experience it yourself then you can feel the nice feeling of the atmosphere of the Old Town of Prague.

Lovely Square.. Full of History and atmosphere.
All the buildings are so beautiful and full of character.
The Clock at the hour when the apostles come out is a must see.

Tourist joint. Stare Mesto may have been a athmospheric centre once, but is transformed in a tourist fair. Shops will in majority offer you souvenirs, T-shirts, cap and all the other standard tourist crap you find in any tourist spot. But in Praghue there is hardly any alternative. (compared to Vienna or Salzburg nearby where the majority of people are locals with all the culture and shops that belong to it) Do not expect to see any authentic Chech culture here. Best experience we had was a visit to the state opera. Never had seen an Opera in my life, but if you want to have the experience this is a good opportunity

Well worth a visit. Apart from the usual places advertised in the guides the square comes alive with the street entertainers during the day (providing the weather is good) we were treated to almost a full brass band whilst eating a pizza. Great views from the clock tower.

Christmas Market Heaven.... We visited Prague during November-December 2011 and the Christmas Markets that were set up were beautiful. Prague is a great city for walking and we walked all over these crazy, people filled streets, with music playing, food vendors galore, and light displays. Old Town is very welcoming and embracing! I love the way the streets get taken over by all of these little shops and restaurants. It's almost as if you are walking through Coney Island, without the rides; one big open Santa Monica Pier.
Moreish !!. If you have never visited the Old town, then you must. It is beautiful and has breathtaking architecture.

See the show at the Astronomical Clock. Old Town is lovely but the highlight has to be the astronomical clock. It's fascinating to see the show on the hour as the clock, built in 1410, comes to life. You are also able to climb the clock tower if you have the stamina and want to see a breathtaking overview of Old Town. Know that the area surrounding the clock will be very crowded with tourist groups but the show is worth it, especially if you read about the history of the clock and it's construction beforehand. Also impressive, in a foreboding way, is the Black Tower and although old town is made up of narrow cobblestone streets, they are relatively easy to navigate and the layout of the area is very straight forward so it's easy to find your way.

old limousine tour. We arrived at the old town by tram It was good looking at the old buildings and we decided to go on one of the classic limo tours which was 32 euros no matter how many passengers there were. The driver was good giving us a running commentary as we went along.

very busy little streets. just loved walking down the little cobbled streets, so much to see around every corner, all the little quaint shops are so lovely and the buildings are out of this world, can't wait to go there again and if i have my way it will be in December again.

Old Town Square. I consider Old Town Square as No.1 on Top 10 of Prague´s turistic attractions. It is very busy all the day. Open place with background of historical buildings in various styles, a lot of restaurants, occasional open air musical performances, occasional markets. And in all directions, there are narrow, winding streets of Old Town.

Astounding Beauty with Lots of Tourists. In short, the buildings and architecture in the Old Town was astounding and abundant. Narrow cobbled streets [wear REALLY good shoes] wind through buildings that centuries old, most having been fully restored. But the best part of the Old Town is observed by looking up! Statuary on almost every building, not to mention the churches, cathedrals, and the Old Town Hall with the beautiful clock and the on-the-hour rotation of the saints popping out of the windows and the skeleton ringing the bell. Lots of restaurants with plenty of variety for every taste. We preferred the sidewalk cafes for the people watching. We were there in early June, so evenings were cool and Prague wasn't as full of tourists as later in the summer. Lots of shops selling tourist souvenirs but also some nice shops with good quality leather products and garnet jewelry. Take your time and walk slowly enough to take it all in. Better yet, depart from the main streets and wander through the back streets and alleyways. That's where we found the best restaurants!
Must visit a very special. I loved the beauty of the square, the monument of King, peace and leisure, shops, special homesDelicious food reasonable prices

A lot of everything. not only cultural heritages everywhere, but events, souvenirs and my TGI Fridays restaurant located in Karlova 20... a lot of stores, old cars, guides for free in the morning, best beer in kiosks, and lots of nice women... just paradise!
Lovely architecture. Lovely old streets to explore and browse the shops. Quite busy, particularly around the square. Lots going on and a great buzz.

Bustling Town Square. This old town square is full of excitement. There always seems to be something going on... food, vendors, music, parades. Lovely restaurants and cafes run alongside so stop by one and relax and people watch for awhile. The views of the old colorful buildings are spectacular! It is truly a one of a kind city!
History and beauty in every corner.... Loved the old buildings and beautiful alleyway in every corner. The place was safe enough with the tourists for nightly stroll. Wished I could've stayed longer.

Lovely square with Easter Market. Prague's Old Town has a multitude of architectural styles and the Square is full of musicians and mimes, restaurants, and so much else to see. We were there during the Easter Market and it was full of booths selling everything from local delicacies to handpainted eggs. Lots of action, and fun to explore the area, and a very real part of Prague.

A must for Prague. Old town is filled with beautiful buildings and churches. The huge square is bustling with galleries, restaurants, street performers and more. It's a major tourist spot and definite must for a Prague visit.
medieval wonder. wandering through the cobblestone streets, everywhere I looked I saw something amazing and breathtaking!

Best Old Town in Europe. Be prepared to walk slowly, eat at a restaurant in a cellar, and spend time exploring all of the nooks and crannies. Plan ahead for some of the more popular concerts, but there is lots to discover. You'll need at least a day here, if not more.
Beautiful buildings and great atmosphere. Just a very cosmopolitan place to sight see and take in this part of the beautiful city. Lots of lovely bars and restaurants to enjoy

One of the best town squares in the world. A bustling, if not touristy, central square with magnificent original architecture. The square is even more wonderful at night when the towers and surrounding buildings are lit up. Climb the clock town on the old town hall and look down on the masses below. Learn about the part of the town hall that was destroyed in the fighting in 1945. Go for a beer in the roof garden of the Hotel U Prince more and majestic view in all directions. Go on a guided tour of the underground city that lies beneath Old Town and remains intact when the raised the street level. Or simply sit in one of the bars and watch the world go by. Loads to do and good any time of day with any age group. A must in Prague.

Too many tat shops. Prague is a beautiful city. The problem is it is over loved. Tourists in general (of which I am one) destroy the character of a great place. To cater for the lowest desires of tourists, there are rubbishy souvenir shops everywhere. I have no idea who buys this stuff.....it always ends up in the rubbish or a boot sale a few years later. These shops are everywhere. There is no individuality. You have to look real hard to find the true crafts and individual retailers rather than the corporate rubbish that is in every European city.But Prague is a beautiful city none the less..

Stunning. No trip to Prague would be complete without a visit here to the hub of the city. In every direction there are magnificent buildings, surrounding the square. Entertainers abound and the square and surrounding streets are full of cafes, restaurants and shops. The roof bar at the U Prince hotel gives a magnificent eagles eye view of all that is going on below.
Birthday visit. All of the sights were beautiful be careful of the Exchange shops a better rate can be got in England
Prague Old Town Square. Beautiful Old town square,cafés pricey but worth it,especially next to the astronomical clock,best view in the house and a nice cold beer to boot!
Prague Old Town. Stunning! the squares and alleys are amazing and the buildings are beautiful. Everywhere you looked they were amazingly decorated. You could walk round all day and never get bored.
Beautiful. Great atmosphere and always lots of entertainment ongoing. Restaurants are more expensive here, but worth splashing out to soak up the atmosphere
Old town. Walking in this area is like waking up in an earlier century.Really amazing!!! I miss it already :D !
Beatyful place!. A very beautyful place yopu have to visit if you are travelling to Prague. If you like the old European buildings this is the place to visit!

Walk amid the history. The buildings, the Clock Tower and the Astronomical Clock, the frescos, the cobblestones. Go back in time in this amazing place. Wander through the tiny streets, shop for Garnets or crystals. A place like no other with lots of places to eat, drink, people watch, encounter buskers. Must do!

the heart of prague. this place is a heart of Prague
its very nice to walk around and have a lunch in this area and buy souvenirs

beautiful!. you can see almost every type of architecture featured on the square side by side.
Head up to the U-Prince hotel terrace for a bite or a drink with the best view of the square and Prague's red roofed skyline...

There is still. There is still an enchanting buzz about the old sector of Prague. And a freedom to take it slow and absorb all the sights without rushing.The square can fill with the Night Markets and was an extra experience of absolute charm. Though the prices aren't cheap; Prague typically offered a great exchange rate with some stalls then seeming expensive - but decent prices really.So much to see and learn about.

I burst forth from the cab, I thought I had died and gone to haaven.. Beautifully vibrant like most European center squares, yet more open and welcoming. You are first awestruck by the wonder St, Vitus only to quickly learn that the astronomical clock was on the right. If you're detailed oriented like I am you'll have much to observe. Don't just pass by. Go up the town at sunset. Take picture from all angels. Unless you return to Prague you'll never see anything quite like it.
Stare Mestro. OK. You know you are going to do the Old Town. All roads lead here. Yes, it is touristy. But it is such a large square, with so much to see and do, it does not feel crowded.

Brings you back in time!. One of the things I really loved about Prague was its "old" feel. One feels like being transported back centuries ago. I admire how the country has preserved all the structures and not give in to the modernity of the times. The cobblestone streets and old buildings are simply beautiful. The city is so picturesque, there is never a bad view! It is simply amazing.

It's just a gorgeous place that must not be missed. This is everyone's dream of Prague. The big plaza is lined with a cool mixture of architectures, Renaissance through Art Nouveau, and important buildings are on the corners: the astronomical clock, the St. Mary on Tyn Church, and the St. Nicholas Husserite church (a little Baroque gem where it's great to catch an evening concert). Several food vendors sell treats like fried dough tubes and sausages, but there are also nice sit-down restaurants featuring sidewalk tables and great people-watching. We saw a Korean team shoot photos of models wearing wedding dresses in front of the clock. Also, often a stage is set up near the interesting Jan Huss statue, a

Grab a seat and watch the world go by.. Prague is one of the most beautiful cities in the world. The Old Town area is so alive and vibrant. Morning noon and especially in the evening its wonderful to sit and watch the towers light up, the people enjoying the atmosphere and savoring life. So much to do and see. I think if a person can only see one European city, it needs to be Prague.

Very interesting. Story has it that these two towers are mis-matched because after the first was built the plans for the second tower were lost so another architect was hired and he did his own interpretation.

Delightful. Walking in this area is like waking up in an earlier century. The streets are cobblestone, the buildings are ornate and beautiful, the pathways are lively with mostly young people (both tourists and locals), restaurants and bars are plentiful. Stay in this area if you can--you won't regret it. We stayed on Old Town Square itself, which was full of life yet quiet by bedtime. Always something to look at, always something to do. Street vendors and street performers add to the experience. This is a place I will always remember and always miss.

Beautiful part of historical Prague. Prague doesn't have "easy" history. In last century World War II and communism did many bad things, but thank God Old Town wasn't demolished. Old Town is quite large area full of beautiful architecture and many of the major attractions of Prague. Take good shoes and forget your clock and wander around narrow alleys and cobblestone streets. Of course full of tourists, souvenir shops etc. But still great local cafes, pubs and restaurants too.
great entertainment. when you need to give your feet a rest, grab a drink in one of the many bars, and watch the street entertainment.

Beautiful!!!. Absolutely beautiful! You walk around looking all the time at lovely architecture. It's busy but just enough to feel a buzz but not be chaotic. Can be romantic & tourist friendly at the same time. Will go back!

A lively spot in an amazing city.. The Old town of Prague really takes your breath away with its beauty. The buildings are well preserved, the streets are very clean, and there are all sorts of happenings in the squares and streets.

A brick. loads to see - street theatre, music of all sorts, galleries, concerts, architecture of every sort, bars, restaurants and shops for every taste and price. Museums about almost everything including the BRICK.

GREAT PLACE - SHAME ABOUT THE TOURISTS. Some stunning streets and buildings - just wander and soak it all in and wonder. Well worth joining a guided walk as the history of some buildings is very interesting. Very busy with tourists but I suppose it wouldn't exist without them and the locals don't seem to resent the surrender of their town centre to the visiting hordes. From the main square you can get motorised guided tours of the whole city in various types of transport including classic Skoda SPORTS CARS !!! You can also use the EKOEXPRESS a road train that takes you up to the Castle area where you can get off and get a later train down - round trip (I think) 240czk. A word of warning there is zero leg room and the combination of solid suspension, cobbles and tram lines does not make for a smooth ride.

Amazing. If you are not staying in the old town, you should go and visit it.It is a lovely old square next to the astronomical clock that has beautiful old building, nice restaurants and good food huts.Lovely to just sit and eat

Stunning buildings and features, early morning get the best of it. Just a stunning place dripping with aching beautiful buildings and features. Really linger and look up at the intricate features of the buidlings. Its easy to get the best from the old square and clock but I enjoyed just wandering. There are tons of people though and you struggle to take a decent photo as a result. I loved walking the old town and bridges early morning (06:00 - 07:00) when there were just a few photographers around and the folk keeping things clean.There is great food to be had in the many restaurants but I would avoid Friday nights when the many stag events see the worst of those there to party. That said, I like a drink myself and simply sitting sipping a great Czec beer watching the world go by is pretty awesome.I would say there isn't a more beautiful city than Prague although those well traveled in this part of the world tell me there is.

An amazing place to visit. if you're in Prague or planning to travel to Prague, it's one of the must see places. Architecture is just amazing. It's always crowded by a lot of tourists, however there are a lot to see. A lot of street artists, tasty TRDELNIK,,, hm you should try it.Astronomical clock is also in the Old Town, National theatre is just a few minutes walk. So it's in the very center and the life is in full swing...

one of the most beautiful and historic squares in Europe. This square is lovely- full of history and architecture. Definitely crowded and sometimes annoying street performers throw off the medieval vibe, but not to be missed.

Beautiful Historical Stroll. Old Town is the perfect place to visit to check out the incredible historical buildings and see some of Prague's most beautiful sights. We didn't go with a guide, preferring to just wander through ourselves and while it was great we did not know what we saw a lot of the time. That being said, a lot of the important buildings have plaques to establish their use (Mostly related to famous people - Kafka, Einstein, etc.) The famous clock is beautiful, make sure you take a stroll across Charles Bridge and check out the Estates Theatre.

Prague (many locations) are quite beautiful. To do Prague well require a minimum of 3+ full days.The area surrounding the Old Town Square has a lot of good sites to see, as well as a lot of good restaurants. (However, not surprisingly, the prices around the Square are somewhat higher than the same items and same quality in the other areas of Prague.
Interesting but. Interesting but not extraordinary. Walk around and look at the shops. The buildings are beautiful. Be prepared for a lot of people .

Great Passagata Spot. Your visit to Prague should include Stare Mesto. It is a great place to have a passagata and then sit in a café and watch the world pass by. The atmosphere is second to none, only problem is there is too many tourists like us.To get a really good impression of the historical architecture we went in the morning before the crowds and enjoyed the astronomical clock when it reached the hour chime (if you don't see - don't worry, it not that great).Only negative aspect was the lack of tourist information and friendly local faces.

Majestic. Beautiful buildings throughout the Old Town. Best visited earlier in the day as crowds tend to build up later. The main street Karlova street joins the Old Town Square to Castle Bridge and has plenty of souvenir shops and restaurants/pubs. Parischzy street has the high-end shops and is close to the Jewish quarter. Celetna street joins the Old Town Square to the Republic Square where the beautiful Municipal House is situated. Would recommend spending 4 hours exploring the area. One can go to the top of the Old Town Square Tower for panoramic views
Great arctitecure. Praha old town is fantastic to walk around. The architecture is just amazing. The place can get a little crowded though.
Great place to visit. A lot of places to enjoy a couple of drinks, enter museums, see the astronomical clock and many other attractions.

great place. It is clean and beautiful, you could go day after day and see new things, very well conserved. We also payed attention no electric wires to disturbe the view. plenty of restaurants with resonable prices.

Hustle & Bustle. Old Town is POPPIN'! Restaurants, churches, government buildings . . Old Town is a slice of what life was like in Prague years ago. It's really quite beautiful! Beware of the masses of tourists / tours; the Astronomical Clock is in Old Town. The clock might look interesting, but as our local friend said, "it is actually one of the most disappointing tourist attractions in the world." People will wait HOURS to see the moving figures pop out. Other than that, Old Town is a nice stop while visiting Prague.

Lovely old buildings - take your time to really look. The square has buskers and street artists and is surrounded but some incredible architecture. Look up at the art on the buildings, they really are lovely.

a must see in Prague. If you have the time, the Old Town Square in Prague is another must see of the city. Shops galore, along with restaurants and one of the most expensive streets you can imagine with stores like "Gucci, Prada, Dior" just to name a few and than there is the church with the clock. Well worth an afternoon or evening for strolling, eating and just plain enjoying the scenery.

Yellow T-Shirt free tour. Loved the narrated walking tour by the Yellow T-Shirts. So informative. Happy to give optional tip for the service. Our guide grew up in Australia, so had lots of good stories we could understand.
Maybe the most beautiful old city in Europe. Winding tiny streets full of shops and restaurants. the Charles Bridge is a fantastic gateway to a picture post card city.

Very well looked after. The old town of Prague is one of the most picturesque in the world. It is lovely to just get lost in the warren of side streets, lined with beautiful facades. It is very cleaned and well looked after.

A wonderful place to walk. Make no mistake: the central business of Prague is tourism. Tens of thousands of them crowd the streets in summer, trailing behind umbrella-toting guides, jamming the Charles Bridge and other sights. But the Old Town is one of the great walking venues in Europe. Lots to see and do, places to shop and eat, historic venues to visit-- all within a manageable boundary. And you don't need a guide to take it all in. The Czechs have become tourism entrepreneurs (there is an admission charge for everything except the ticket office) but unless you buy something at a restaurant or shop, most of the venues in the Old Town are free. We took several leisurely strolls and enjoyed them very much.
Overnight in Prague. I liked everything and no dislikes other than the high number of tourists. The Charles bridge was particularly busy as was the Old Square.
Great place. Brilliant!!! Fantastic part of the city that needs to be deeply explored to find hidden gems at every corner, alleys, etc.
Magical transportation through time!. Incredible collection of medieval architecture fronted by street cafes! Make sure to climb to the top of the Old Town Centre for a better view!
Go get lost. Get away from the tourists and just walk around without a map and you'll find that every corner presents something new and beautiful.

Just walking around.... in the old town (including the square) we really enjoyed a lot, doing with with no particular purpose except experiencing it. Lots of buildings worth seeing and possibilities for having a good snack and and excellent beer.

One of the mos beautiful places in Europe. I am just in love with Prague... This city is beautiful, and it seems that you never stop discovering new charming places... And Prague by night is just absolutely amazing!

paradise for lovers of history and architecture. Every where you look on the old Town Square there is an interesting building or church not forgetting the wonderful astronomical clock. All round the square are restaurants where you can sit and enjoy the atmosphere. Venture off the square and there are fascinating streets and alleyways and yet more beautiful buildings. I would recommend staying in the Old town to get the most from your visit

Very nice place although very crowded. Eberything, restaurants and coffee bars at square are a rip off. If possible do not use taxis but the tram and metro. Many if not most taxi drivers are not honest..

Beautiful, romantic place to go. Prague is one of the most beautiful European cities and its Old Town is the heart of history, architecture, culture and arts.It's an amazing place for couples where every corner brings a hit of romance.Food is very cheap and so delicious. Oh, beer as well!I was visiting Prague around Christmas and it was just one more plus comparing to the other European capitals we always talk about.

Give yourself plenty of time to just wander.... My neck got sore just from looking up all the time ;-)So much to see and so much you could miss if you don't hire a local guide to help you discover the real Praha under the tourist veneer. Great value to really get the most out of your Prague visit.
Amazing history. My advice to all travelers is to stay in the Old Town regardless of the hotel. This is the center of Prague and everything worthwhile is in Old Town. Loved it! Loved it! Loved it!

center of everything. lots of things to see and do. it is a really fun place. we watched dancers, battles between knights, and singers. all for free. their style was about the 1000 to 12 hundreds. lots of street food venders. watch your money because they only take crowns or paper euros. the money is a pain. we felt very safe and the people were so fun. had a great time.

if you loves history. Prague is one of the most beautiful city in Europe, and the old city makes 90% of the impression. Read the history of the Country and be ready to know something nice and new from the guide whom you absolutely must to take during the visiting the Old city, just because of too much information.
A walk in the past. Wonderful old buildings beautifully preserved! The U Prince Hotel roof terrace is a must for panoramic views during the day and cocktail at night.
Beautiful!. A must see when you're in Prague, the Old Town area is full of interesting details every which way you turn.

Don't miss it. Beautiful. One of the most beautiful places in Prague. You really can't miss it. This part of town is the best and where you will spend the majority of your time. If you don't know Czech, English is "kind of" understood, but Italian is everywhere and for that reason, Spanish works a little too.The area is full of attractions, amazing streets, shops, bars, restaurants and is very safe.
Enchanting. Old town is pretty beautiful and its atmosphere is amazing, with all those shops, restaurants, bars and lots of people enjoing everything. It's like aparty at open air.

Beautiful Place. The old town is an architectural masterpiece, which has a fantastic atmosphere. The architecture is next to none melding the Baroque with the gothic. The astronomical clock which is absolutely beautiful is why you visit the old town. It is a gem. Have a coffee, have some traditional Czech food and just soak up the atmosphere. There are many restaurants, a little food market and shops surrounded by the beautiful buildings. Look around as you can find free tours that explain the history of the old town square. I had a book as I prefer to do it at my own pace. The old town square literally is something out of a fairytale. The Tyn church in particular is Disney-esque-it is even said that Walt Disney got the inspiration for the Magic Castle from the Old Town Square. It is an absolutely beautiful place, unique in the whole of Europe.
Spectacular. Everywhere you look there is some more beautiful than the other!!!! Breath taking! A definite must do when in Prague

Picturesque but hordes of tourists. Old Town is quaint and picturesque but is overrun by tourists, who often form a wall-to-wall river of people from the Charles Bridge to Old Town Square. The streets are lined almost entirely with shops catering to tourists. We often circumvented this route (although you can't avoid the packed Charles Bridge) by a few blocks and found only a few locals and the odd tourist.

Don't miss the amazing architecture!. You haven’t seen Prague if you don’t visit the old town. A variety of architecture from different centuries which keeps you walking without noticing the distance. You can find free tours in the old town square. Those are walking tours. I suggest you register for one of them. At the end you have to tip the tour leader but it’s really nothing. The leader made the old town much more meaningful for us.

A coffee at the old town. Very nice! Breathtaking! It was crowded but that didn't affect the beauty of the buildings and their history. Having a coffee at one of the restaurants there was a total pleasure

Amazing architecture and fairy tale structures. It's as if you're in a fairy tale world. It's stunning from the moment you cross over Charles Bridge and enter the Old Town. You can't help but be stunned by the beauty of the old world structures around you. As another reviewer said, you truly are looking up at the beautiful architecture and not even paying attention to anything that is at eye level. I was separated numerous times from our guide because I was too busy looking up and taking pictures. Walt Disney's castles and fantasy villages must have been partly inspired by the charm and beauty of Old Town. There's something magical about this place. You feel it all around you. It can get very crowded, and you do have to watch where you're going at times. People will stop in front you because they are also taking pictures and admiring the beauty all around them. There are so many attractions to see, and not enough time to do it all in one day. We booked a private day tour from Vienna. It was a great experience, but we should have stayed there another day. That was probably our only regret. If you can, stay in the city for a couple of days for an even better experience.

Take time to explore Praugue Old Town. It depends what you like of course! If you don't like places that cater for mass tourism, selling horrible gifts, pushy waiters and drunk people then avoid the main tourist sights after lunchtime and in the evening particularly at the weekend. Avoid eating near the main squares you will find much better quality service if you keep walking through the windy streets away from the crowds. The old town is 600/700 years old and fascinating, there are magnificent churches tucked away in the side streets, go to the Old Town Square in the morning if you don't like crowds. You will admire the Baroque and Gothic buildings and the fantastic astronomical clock -arrive for this on the hour.
CCCU. Charles Bridge, Old Town Square and clock tower, Prague Castle, Old Town shopping area and street performers in Old Town Square...no dislikes...

Fun to wander about. Great atmosphere, wonderful architecture-just start walking and get lost, there is plenty to do and see. When you are exhausted and feet hurt, grab a drink in one of the many street cafes or restaurants and have fun people-watching

The pumping heart of Prague. Can't miss it, the heart of Prague, flowing with tourists street shows and cafes!
You can reach many main attractions in a walking distance from here.
Stunning. Beautiful buildings, clean streets, not too busy with tourists. A map is handy as it can get confusing but otherwise, enjoy! (Lovely shops along the way too)

Grab a beer and watch the show. Old Town Prague is filled with wonderful buildings from the Middle Ages through the Art Nouveau period. There is so much to see as you walk the narrow winding streets. Grab a beer in one of the outdoor restaurants and watch the show when the Astronomical Clock strikes the hour.

Stunning Place. This place is worth visiting. It's historical centre of Prague. Must see the hourly show of Astronomical Clock. Then climb to the top of old town tower to enjoy the view of old town. Lovely area

History all around. Beautiful spot in a beautiful city, but you will have trouble getting a picture of your friend without getting others in it. It was packed when we visited and it wasn't even a weekend.

Love it. Beautiful buildings. The old town in Prague must have the oldest buildings which are still in such a good state. Some of those buildings are magnificent such as the Municipal building. Great place. An absolute must to visit the old town.

Wonderful sights, busy on a Saturday night!. I loved the architecture of the buildings . Weekends are busy in the centre. Prices for food and drink are inexpensive.
The hop-on-hop-off bus tour was a bit disappointing with little information being given via pre-recorded info. On headset.

One of the Best Places in Europe!. I could spend days, maybe weeks, just wandering around Old Town. The cobblestone streets wind around and if you allow yourself to just follow wherever your feet lead you, you will find the most wonderful things, from antiquarian bookstores and shops that carry vintage cameras, to little bars that serve Absinthe. Old Town is a shopper's paradise, from tourist junk to gorgeous glassware, there is something for everyone. You'll be forgiven if you miss a lot of what's at street level because most of the time you'll be walking around with your head bent backwards, looking up at all the fabulous buildings. Don't miss the clock in the square, get there before the hour chimes because the show only lasts a couple of minutes and everyone wants to see it! There is so much to do and see you'll need to come back again and again.

History on tik tok. The old town has lots of things to offer like clock show after every hour which attracts a no.of people , the squre itself and the churches especially tyn church is one of the most beautiful churches i have ever visited having beauty from inside as well as outside. Try taking a 3 hour free tour(tip tour) as they show you both new and old town.

Cute, cute, cute. Filled with tourists, but the architecture of the various buildings facing it are fascinating. There are food stalls and cafes galore, and the place is just full of atmosphere. Sit a while and absorb it, breathe it in and thank yourself for going there.

Tourist shops. Every store sells the same trinkets , you can negotiate prices.
Good for souvenirs for the kids! A lot of stuff is average quality!
Gorgeous!. Just absolutely gorgeous! Sat at night watching the sun set with a glass of wine listening to some great music. Probably one of my best nights there! A must see and a must to experience!

Nice stroll through the Old Town. We had a magical day. It was in the summer and super weather for walk, not so hot, The architecture is stunning. Go visit in winter, Christmas market and hot wine is just must.

All year round treat.. Though we travelled in May 2014, I would want to return and absorb the atmosphere at Christmas. The 'Old Town' has so much to offer, from a historical point and with so many bars and cafes, you can people watch for hours.. For future visitors don't try and rush your visit to Prague in a couple of days. Soak up the culture and the theatres. Make your trip a minimum of 5 days.
the most goth place ever. I really like this city, its really goth. I'd like to live in Prague. The old town amazed me. just amaaaazing

Buzzy, Baroque, Brilliant!. Street entertainers, Astronomical Clock & climbing the Tower. Also worth visiting is the Old Town Hall & it's Gothic cellars. Great walk from Petrin Tower to the Monastry and the Bellavista restaurant terrace for a beer and the best view of Prague. Also be brave & try the absinthe!
Wander and get lost. In the twists and turns of old town. See the open market, historic churches, winding streets. Loved it.
Great At Christmas. Stayed in Prague over Christmas. It was fantastic ! The Old Square at night was magical, especially on Christmas Eve.
Great energy. So much happening in this area of the city--lots of students/young people, giving it great energy. And the historical spots and restaurants are worth a visit.

A must see. I enjoy this old town as history provides its backdrop. The old library is worth the money you spend just to appreciate how its well done. Restaurants follow along the course at your own leisure and are less costly than in the old.new town. Infant Jesus, Kafka museum is in this area as well.

amazing place to walk. this place is nice to walk, take tons of pictures, shop and stop foe a coffee or even better a beer!
Make sure to have very comfortable flat shoes to walk around, the streets stones unable any heels.
Good times. Wandered around here for ages, plenty to see and do. There seems to always be something going on, excellent.

one of the most beautiful places in Europe. Prague's Old Town is one of the most beautiful places in Europe. It is truly stunning. Make sure you stay to see the animated clock perform on the hour. In addition, a trip to the top of the tower gives an amazing view. This is truly a city of spires. We also enjoyed the Mucha/Dali museum. This is a must stop for Prague.

Walk around and take it all in. When you go to Prague stay near this awesome area. Som much beautiful architecture, shops, restaurants, street vendors,etc....we went when it was cold and the had mulled wine and hot chocolate for sale which was great to stay warm. During the summer they probably have ice cream and cold drinks. My kids loved this area, we let them run around and chase birds and burn off some energy. They loved the clock and the atmosphere as a whole. Make sure you check it out, I do recommend eating a bit off the beaten path (5-10 min walk from the square) if you want better selections and cheaper prices...enjoy.

Charming area of Prague. The Old Town is beautiful, quaint, has cobblestone streets that twist and turn. We took a wrong turn and couldn't imagine a more charming place in which to be lost. We took lots of photos as everywhere we looked there was something beautiful.

Nice place to go. It is a classic town where everything is still preserved.It is worthy to stroll around this old town to enjoy the vibrance and scenery around it.From the castle, it can be reached quite easily either by tram/metro or just walking.
wow. One of the most beautiful and charming places in the world. All the buildings in the Old Town are amazing,Definitely a must see,
Prague Old Town. A beautiful part of a beautiful city. This is where everything happens - Disney towers, astronomical clocks, concerts, food stalls and lots of tourist shops.

The heart of prague. From the square for the clock and everything else, to all the nice restaurants and breweries in the area, to shopping on the main street. Just walk around and get lost, you'll enjoy it more this way.
Prague tour. A good quick way to see the best of Prague. Good shops and the eating places were inexpensive for a city centre.

Medieval Europe at it's best. Walking through old town Prague is a feast for the eyes. Between the old churches, the statues, the buildings, and the astronomical clock there is so much to see and many protographic opportunities. It is more beautiful in person then in pictures.

Such a beautiful place. It is such a beautiful place. Cobbled streets, cute little stone shops and cafes. This little town is so cute and has a lovely atmosphere. Definitely worth a few hours wondering around.

The Most Beautiful Medieval Europe!!. Prague has the best Medeival European architecture simply because it escaped most of the conflict of the last millenium. Most wars ended long before the invaders could reach this far, so the bridges and buildings remain largely unscathed. Crossing over the Karli Most from the West you ente the old quarter of the city, and it is absolutely beautiful. The buildings, churches and towers are breath-taking, and the old astronomical clock is a wonder. The markets in the area are quaint with many wonderful cafes and pubs to entertain the traveller. A Hint - the tourist shops in the centre of town are no more eexpensive than anywhere else.
Just another great view. Every corner has another thing to look at. This will not disappoint so just wander round and enjoy this great place.
One of a kind. There is no other old town in the world like Old Town Prague. It will move you. It will take you centuries back.
So Historical!. A bit crowded but extremely nice! Very historical!The Astronomical clock is a must see! Especially the hourly show which is not all that but still quite nice!
Beautiful and steeped in history.... You can't go wrong here - something for everyone. Immerse yourself in history and culture - along with fabulous, reasonably priced food and drink!
interesting mix of architecture. Way too many people. We went in the morning. Better to go later in the day. You will not go hungry in the area.
Charming. There is nothing to add about old Prague: charming and compact city. Get a nice guidebook and daily travel pass and you are done.

The Best of Europe. Old Town epitomizes what pre War, historic, Europe must have been like. It's Cathedrals, Concert Halls, narrow old cobble-stone streets, towers, exquisite restaurants, & spires, as well as it's many shops, make it a great place to visit. Combine this with the Lesser Town across the Charles Bridge & it's difficult to envison a more enjoyable city in Europe to visit.

Beautiful heart of the city. We traveled all over Europe for 6 weeks and Prague with it's beautiful Old Town was perhaps our favorite place we visited. So much has been said about Prague's old town that I don't feel like I have much to add other than I can't recommend it highly enough.
one of the best cities in Europe. great city with lots to see and do good choice of Restraunts. will definatley come back, hopefully for longer next time

Amazing Vibe and Lots to see. Even if you had not planned to go to the Old Town, passing it on a bus or on a walk, you are are compelled to stop. It has so much energy and an amazing vibe. I loved it. I bought myself a local beer from one of the stalls and drank it slowly as I took in my surroundings. The building designs and architecture were amazing: churchs, museums, belltower... take your pick so much to take in. Such an old world charm. You are compelled to join all the other tourists to frantically click your camera to try and capture the wonder that is before you. There are lots of cafes and bistros surrounding the square. I also tried the local street cuisine of smoked ham and mini donuts with a selection of sauces. Yum! It is definitely A MUST SEE/VISIT while in Prague. However be warned. It is crowded and there are lots of tourists. So while enjoying the sights, be street smart for pick pockets.

Gorgeous Fairy Tale Setting Smothered with Tourist Kitsch. The buildings are magical, combining characteristics of Medieval, Baroque, Renaissance, and Art Deco, right out of a fairy-tale setting. Too many fantastic scenery pictures to take - as the camera doesn't do it justice. Besides the beautiful towers, churches, museums and hundreds of shops housed in the most eclectic assortment of varied architecture, the view from the Charles (and other) bridges are spectacular. Wear comfortable walking shoes (no heels for the ladies, as all roads are essentially small and large rough-hewed cobbles) and watch for pick-pockets and money-changes on the street - if the deal seems too good to be true, it usually is (counterfeit currency is used). Plenty of shops (high and low-end), tons of restaurants at all price points, and tour guides available to guide you thru the myriad of street entertainers, artists, and various other "artists" - some are quite good, and others are clearly "artistically challenged...". Many different neighborhoods and plenty of outdoor seating for experiencing the open-air beauty of that which is Prague.

Cobblestones. Lots of cobblestones so make sure you've comfy footwear, plenty to see but get a map from the hotel. Most people speak some form of English. Try the local food especially the goulash it's delish.
Old Town. The Old Town just has to be seen! The buildings were majestic. There was also plenty of pubs and cafe bars along with the usual fast food outlets that you see at home.
Touristy area. There are hundreds of tourists wandering around, taking pictures and locals of all ages enjoying sunny days.

Meeting place for all. This is the centre of nearly all that happens in Prague lovely monuments the astronomical clock all roads lead to this square it seems, a very busy little place, we absolutely loved it, 10 minute walk to the Charles bridge a great place to visit, with buskers everywhere such a great atmosphere, make sure you always have some small change on you for the toilets, as to visit them it costs you 10 cents/crown cz, all the people we met were very friendly and cheerful and eager to help, the local food was a treat you have to try it

Fun place to be. We were there when the Czech Republic was playing Finland in Ice Hockey in the semi-finals for the world championship. They had a large screen set up in the square as well as a platform for a band. It was a fun time! There's also great stands with great food and drink as well as great cafes lining the area!
Heart... We stayed in The Imperial Hotel on Na Porici in the old town which was very good and had easy access to the sites on foot

yellow umbrella free walking tours. We tried a free walking tour and were escorted on a three hour tour of Old town, the Jewish quarter, and New town. Our guide was Cullum, an Australia with the required accent! He was very knowledgeable and told us the history of the Astronomical Clock as well as many churches and historical sites around the town. He also informed us of scams and practices to be aware of. They survive on tips and Cullum was very worthy of a substantial tip.
The beating heart of Prauge. The view in Old town never gets old. It's like a movie set with red roofs and mixed architecture that charts history of the last thousand years.
The old town. Beautiful, colourful old buildings but very crowded even though it was only May and unseasonally chilly.
MUST SEE in Prague. This is THE center of Prague - it's a must-see. If you can do a walking tour of the area, you will learn a lot about the fascinating history of Prague.

Like walking round in a fairytale.. I've yet to find a part of Prague I don't think is worth visiting. BUt the old town is really something special. Make time to stroll around it during the day and again at night. It does the heart good. The Czechs have done a beautiful job of preserving the character and indigenous architecture of the whole city and nowhere is that more apparent than here.
Beautiful place. The whole of the old town is a wonderful place to just walk around. The streets are all clean and tidy, beautifully cobbled and full of history.

Amazing if you don't mind the crowds. The old town square is an amazing place, it is like stepping back in time. The clock is defiantly a must see as is the town hall and the gates. When we were the tourist crowds were thick which detracted from the experience of enjoying the square as we had to focus on navigating through the crowds.

If you don't mind crowds, go for it, we did & we are seniors.. Saturday evening visit, music festival going on while there, not our type of music, but Hay, it's an atmosphere to enjoy over-all. Historic and interesting buildings and sights, yes it was crowded, but public safety and police had it covered. Stayed late after the concert closed and enjoyed our photo ops. and we closed out the night with a our choice from the pubs in the area.
A city that must be visited. So much to see and do but the cafes and restaurants are cheap and the staff very friendly. Cafe Mozart is a must go upstairs in the afternoon and listen to the pianist.

Beautiful piece of history. We had a marvelous time walking around the Old Town square. In fact, I think it was my favorite part of the trip. The best feature, in my opinion, was the Astronomical Clock. It's the oldest functioning astronomical clock in the world, and it puts on a little show every hour. The square tended to fill up as the hour drew closer, so if you want a great view, get there early.
Don't go on a Sunday if you can avoid it. Very noisy and full of tourist trap restaurants. But you have to go there when visiting Prague, just try and choose a quiet time if there is such a thing.
beautiful. Old town is beautiful as always, but beware if You are not used to crowds, especially on the way to Charles bridge
shops history and BEER!. Good place to walk around and see the astrological clock and other historical sites. Good place to familiarize yourself with what Prague has to offer.

Picture perfect. An American chap we were walking with commented that those who built the old town must have visited Disneyland, the towers, turrets and buildings being so picture perfect and replicating Disney so accurately. A joke of course (I hope) but clearly Walt had to have a template to create his fairy tale world and old Prague must have been it. The architecture and history here are fascinating. For those who want to shop, this is the place. Be aware though, that the Bohemian glass available throughout the old town, is genuine if Bohemia is somewhere in China. Of the old town area, the most interesting is around the old square but there are places in the old Jewish Quarter worth visiting such as the Pinkus synagogue. The Charles Bridge is a must. For eating and drinking purposes, as usual, steer clear of the square, prices are highly inflated for the tourists, nothing unusual in any city but avoidable if you want. There are some excellent international restaurants in the area if the heavy Czech cuisine is not to your liking. The old town is pedestrian so the trams don't access it but rather travel around it. They are still useful to get to the outside of the old town. Be aware that the tram stations to the castle are a haven for pickpockets working in teams. Nevertheless, this has to be one of the most beautiful and quaint places anywhere in Europe. We loved it.

Absolute MUST. This is what people think of when they refer to visiting Prague. Walk around and see bohemian glass/crystal shops, Czech food and beer, multiple historic churches, oldest anatomical clock, the unique side streets, etc. It's the epitome of Prague!Yes, there are tourist everywhere but it's because everyone must see this beautiful area.

Excellent place to chill out. Lovely place to chill out and enjoy a coffee in the morning and a nice glass of wine in the afternoon. Listen to the street music players and watch the clock do its show every hour. Also the clock tower is an amazing place to take scenic photographs from. Loved this place visited every day twice a day during our four day trip. Best place in Prague.

Classic town with wonderful buildings. Very nice town. Many ancient buildings are very beautiful. This place is easily accessible by public transport. Charles Bridge that is located not far from the Old Town is a place which is incredible in my opinion.

Must see. Could everywhere, plenty of cafés and interesting things to see. The Jewish quarter a must see and the castle, also the communist museum. One thing we found irritating was everyone smoked, but thankfully not indoors

Charming place. One of the most beautiful and charming places I've ever visited. All the buildings in the Old Town are amazing, and the attention to detail is incredible. So many attractions here, all of them unique. Definitely a must see, although a bit expensive if you plan visiting all the touristic buildings.
Mandatory. Can't not go here to see the clock, etc. Many booths with delicious meats cooked over wood fires, also try the palacenka (crepes).

Authentic. Prague is for wandering and one wants to wander here, with places of interest which are more than a thousand years old cheek to jowl with every elegant boutique from Prada to Escada. It is a wonderful contrast of then and now.

Awesome step back in time. Having spent 5 weeks traveling Europe, this was one of my favorite areas. Unspoiled and charming, it's hard to find many places left in Europe that's not changed dramatically in the last century. But here, you step back in time seeing things as they were centuries ago. Tons of shops, eateries, bakeries (and great ones at that). People watch, historic sites, and much more, all in one area. Be sure to try several different restaurants and bakeries. We were there in March, and it wasn't very crowded at all. Prices were low and our hotel was amazing! 968sf for $65 USD a night in the heart of Old Town!!! Tons of historic attractions in the old town area. A must visit area.

Buildings are so amazing. Just walk around Old Town, there is just so much to see. The architecture alone is worth the walk, also the different vendors on the streets but I wouldn't eat here. A very intriguing town with lots to see at every new street you turn into.
Very interesting area. The old town square is fascinating especially the Astronomical Clock! Take your time to explore all the streets and alleyways! They are extremely interesting.

Prague at its Best!. Old Town Square seems to the heart of Prague. It is a wonderful place to people watch - especially fun to watch the crowds as they watch the astronomical clock. Beautiful buildings, good restaurants, fun.
Wonderful. The old town is the best way to spend half a day just walking around, admiring the wonderful buildings and just soaking in the atmosphere.
Must see. Great place for people looking, don't eat on the square, better places, though the street vendors are interesting
terrific. It is an astonishing thing to see. The arquitecture of the buildings is amazing, all buildings have at least one detail that make them unique.
Old school charm. A must see for people of all ages- talk about an old school european charm and this sums it all up in one place. EXCELLENT

Part and parcel of Prague-impossible to miss. It's the heart of a Prague. It stands to reason that one would visit it. There is much to choose from. All is close by and fabulous: old town square, astronomical clock, Spanish Synagogue, old and new Synagogue, street performers...great place

A great part of the city to stay. Old Town is great! I would recommend my friends and most of you to stay there. It is full of great architecture and you can walk to most any hip places and historical sites within a half hour at most. There are also lots of great shops in old town.
Just a reall ynice place to walk, eat and drink. We visited Prague on a Weds/Thurs/Fri so didn't hit the real weekend crowds - so it wasn't overcrowded and the attactions in the square are lovely.

Walk and Explore. This old town is full of nooks and crannies to explore - plenty of shops (especially the puppet ones!), many good restaurants, plenty of out door cafes where to have a beer, cultural venues, trams - a lot going on. All fun with super photo taking opportunities.

Beautiful place. Praha is one of the most beautiful cities in the world, if not the most. But it gets too crowded of tourists sometimes. If you can visit during mid and low seasons, ou will enjoy much mor your visit. The Praha old town is a really beautiful place, where you can have some great Czech street food and many great Bohemian beers at a reasonable price.

Beautiful city for all day. We visited Prague during Easter, when the old town is full of wooden markets and people, but still charming. The atmosphere was great, traditional Czech cuisine was delicious. Don`t miss performance of the astronomical clock (Orloj), but also walking in the lovely narrow streets leading to the square with numerous souvenirs shops, restaurants and bars. You never know, what you can find.
Bustling. Plenty to see and soak up the atmosphere of this great city. Easter market was on so a bonus was colourful decorated stalls and lots of local food and beer on offer.

Breathtaking.. You come to Prague well prepared in advance, everyone talking about its beauties, but to be in the Old Town for real is something really emotional. Everything is of high standard, the multicolour houses perfectly renovated, the lively atmosphere.Great place.
Amazing city. The hub of it all and very beautiful it is too. Could do with a million less tourists though! Head there very early for really good look round.

Go for a stroll at dusk. There is something about this part of Prague that is so Old World and romantic. It must be the cobblestone pathways and the old style street lamps. In the evening it's at its most beautiful. I regret not making the time to ride in a horse-drawn carriage. The multitude of shops and restaurants are also so charming. I can't wait to come back!

Busy and entertaining!. We enjoyed spending time in Old Town Square while visiting Prague. We ate at two different restaurants on the square so we could watch what was going on there. There was lots of entertainment and of course the crowds that gathered every hour to watch the movement of the astronomical clock. Lots of variety of buildings and people and great shops and restaurants and street entertainment too!
Architectural Gem. We were overwhelmed by the great variety of architectural styles, the lovingly preserved buildings, the sheer variety of shops, restaurants, theaters & places of interest.
Simply charming!. The old town is steeped in culture and charm.Spend half a day just soaking in the atmosphere.Check out the art gallery or just watch the world go by.
prague...beautiful city... we loved everything about prague.get up early to miss the crowds and wander the deserted streets.... magic!.

Must see. This neighborhood has several mut see places. The most famous is the Staromestsky namesti (Staromestsky square). But there are museums, churches and small art galleries (where you can buy paintings), etc. around the square.
Old Town Square - fun. Was super busy, so difficult to walk around and during our stay the Prague Marathon started which made it even more challenging. Still fun, though
Awesome collection. This is what people come to Prague to see. Not to be missed. The only drawback is the crowds. Our guide said that it's high season most of the year.
Great Old Town. The old town in Prague is really vast with many things to see. You can't miss Charles Bridge, the Castle, and Prague astronomical clock, part of the old town hall clock tower.

don't miss. We went during Easter market. Square was very crowded. We were there when clock went off. We didn't plan this just happened. I guess if it is the only mechanical clock you see it is interesting. I would not go out of my way to see movement. The square is beautiful and view from tower is wonderful but also crowded.

Enjoyed wandering in a maze of history. You wander around the streets and admire all the views of beautiful buildings, plus there is no limit to the restaurants and pubs. Every single pint of beer that I sampled was great - and I sampled a whole lot!
Open-air museum. Prague is a wonderful city; you can walk for weeks, months, you'll never see the end of all the great buildings.
OLd Town Prague. Fascinating place with lots to see and many restaurants of variety to eat. The Basilica of St Nicholas is worth a visit and of course don't forget the wonderful Astronomical Clock
Bells in the square. Lots going on. Wait for the tower bells to ring, and try to get directly in front of the clock. This is the number one square to visit

Great atmosphere all day. Great food stalls, exciting gift selection and always thriving with visitors. Get to the astronomical clock 10 minutes early on the hour and get up close for the clock to strike on the hour. Amazing.
Beautiful. There are restaurants, cafés, tour guides, live entertainment, and more. The weather I went in was perfect and the place is vibrant and beautiful.

Crowded. As the clock nears the hour to strike, you can hardly move on the square. Watch your pockets! We couldn't find our way into the church that looms over the square - apparently one has to go down an alley between other buildings built right in front of the church

Wonderful. Amazing city !
The old city is wonderful, the building are gorgeous !
I advise you to visit in in 3 hours with one of the free tour in front of the astronomical clock
A must do !
WOOOOW. Great place with history and most like was old nusic in front of monumet.I had no coment just watch.

Amazing!. The old town is fantastic! The ideal place to get lost.
One little annoyance: we've been approached by a beggar that became very angry because we did not have coins to spare.

Gorgeous buildings. Beautiful buildings and history all around with multitudes of shops and restaurants....all cobblestone streets and alleys. Mobbed with people. I enjoyed the hustle and bustle and especially the shop, MANUFACTURA, that sells only handmade Czech items including the famous hand painted egg ornaments amongst lots of wonderful other things. Hiighly recommend that shop!
A Must. Full of interesting things to see including the astronomical clock and old town hall, Charles Bridge and many others

full of activity. Great location, when we`re visited there was an Easter market. Full of people, so loads of people watching! we booked a tour to get around and learn a bit more about its history. We booked a free tour with sandemans.
Perfect 4 day break to Prague. Wonderful place full of wonderful sights and buildings . Views spectacular people really nice food amazing
Fun on the square. Vibrant square a definite on your visit to prague. See the clock as well as art exhibitions. But don't eat or drink at the restaurants on the square, pure tourist traps

Beautiful, all within easy walking distances, lovely streets with so much to explore. This neighborhood, with it's restaurants, interesting shops and lovely history is the highlight of the beautiful city of Prague
Feeing Prague !. This is where prague lives , must be here if you are in prague , don't just look around and think where to go , this is the place you need to be and rest explore yourself

So many people..... Yes, it's beautiful. The main square lacks atmosphere due to the enormous number of tourists, but go a bit off the main streets, best at late evening or in the night and you will feel the magic.

Charming but overrated. Historic charm but the hourly Astronomic clock chimes are wildly overrated. Great starting point for many walking adventures but the all the regular tourist traps are present so be aware. Go early if possible to beat the crowds.
Fill Prague. You can fill spirit of Prague in this place. Just walk and take photos. Do not eat or drink anything here, because prices are higher than normal

The Center of Prague. Here you will experience restaurants, museums, activities, pubs, clubs, souvenirs, buskers, landmarks, churches, and more. You will most likely pass through the Old Town several times during your holiday and most likely will be staying in one of the hotels. Make sure you hotel is not above a late night eatery or club. Revelers' joy can echo through the stone facades and the cobblestones. The area is very safe and your only worry should be of the opportunistic pick pocket.Beware of the "Crystal Mafia" as the locals call it. Unless you know about crystal or gems you should leave that junk at the souvenir shops. Wandering through the streets is fun but there are no grids here. Take a map or have your GPS ready. It is easy to get lost on a side street.

agreat time to visit. We were lucky enough to be here when the weather was warm and sunny and the Easter market stalls were still up. We bought handmade wooden toys for our grandsons. Climb the tower for an impressive view of the city, or take the elevator to the top if stairs are not your thing. Stop for a drink or meal in one of the many cafes. And if you like jewelry, don't pass up the beautiful garnet pieces, although you should do some research before you go so you shop at a reputable dealer. Be sure to get the tax exempt forms from the seller to get that VAT tax back.
Must see attraction. Wonderful, great atmoshere, the best to walk all around passing also aside streets not only the touristic ones...very crouded

Place full of history and beer. We loved the winding streets of old town. Beautiful architecture, lots of restaurant, pub, old buildings with interesting stories about them. We got lost a lot of times, but had never minded since in each turn we found some interesting sites.

A visit to the 15th century. Colorful, interesting buskers, nice area to walk, astrological clock was interesting, especially enjoyed touring the old synagogue and the Jewish cemetery. Lots of history

Plenty to see and do. Prague is a beautiful city, with an amazing number of well-preserved buildings - a range of architecture to enjoy. The old part (Stare Mesto) with its cobbled streets in particular is wonderful to wander through. There can be a lot of tourists so take it slow, give yourself time at the different attractions, stop for a coffee or a bite. Enjoy.

Very interesting cobbled streets, bars restaurants and shops.. Lovely architecture, quaint streets. However it was extremely busy, you can hardly move for tourists. We were warned about pick pockets. Restaurants are good but cater for tourists.

Magical. Although littered with numerous souvenir shops and price inflated restaurants, the Old Town is simply magical. It is even more beautiful at night. It is very crowded with tourists, but if you get up early enough or stay out late, it will be a lot less crowded.
charming .... you have to go and see by yourself. It has been preserved with love and pride. The atmosphere is there, and services are quite effective
Interesting. Prior to the communist invasion, the Chez Republic must have been a beautiful city. The buildings are still beautiful but terribly run down, it is still worth a visit.

Beautiful, but very crowded. Old Town is an absolute must see, as long as you are prepared for every traveler to Prague having it on their must see lists as well!We were lucky enough to have both good weather and the appearance of an Easter festival when we visited. Just because the fried bread, crepes, fried cheese, and fried potatoes are probably tourist fare didn't make them any less delicious. All of the restaurants surrounding the area are definitely targeted at tourists, so if you are hungry you may want to walk a little further out. Even in the off season, it was PACKED -- I can't imagine what it must be like in summer...Take photos, enjoy the atmosphere, and relish in your tourist status! Sometimes the most popular places are popular for a reason!
It's beautiful. Prague is beautiful just to walk around, even at night. You feel very safe but should take care of your stuff anyway as in every big city there are thiefs.

Simply beautiful. There are no words to describe the architecture of all the different buildings. Best enjoyed early morning before the crowds arrive. It is simply breathtaking. Try to catch the clock at 6 or 12 to see all the parts move.

fantastic romantic architecture, tho' very busy.. The architecture was just wonderful. Great atmosphere and history. Fantastically restored. Around the astrological clock it was around the hour really busy. The bars / restaurants here are very touristy. That's not our thing so we ate at little out of the way places.

This is the history of the heart of Europe. Beautiful buildings from a different period of history all next door to one another so as you glance around you seem to see the history of architecture in just one square. During Easter time (April), Old town square is filled with small booths that sell food and easter-related items. So, when we visited, the square was basically bustling with this activity. It was quite charming although very crowded.

It's so happy and full of food stands. Probably has some king of Easter festival now.great food great service. Just hold tight to your bag cause there's lots of poeple and you never know who's looking at your pocket.
Inevitably Prague. Plus: Atmosphere, sights, architecture and shopping.Minus: Crowded to a maximum.Just go there - this is inevitably Prague.
Convenient to the Kempinski Hotel and .... The Old Town Square was close to the Kempinski Hotel and packed full of things to do over Easter 2014.

Friendly people, historical sights, good shopping. We spent three days in Prague just around the corner from the Old Town Square. The square hosted an Easter market and the bustling atmosphere was great. Prague draws many tourists, but once you're in the Old Town, you know that they're right to come here. Great stores, many museums for every taste (Tim Burton exhibition on one corner, the torture museum at the other and then you mustn't forget about all the churches), good food (value for money) and the only thing overpriced are the soft drinks in bottles (50 crowns for a 5dl-bottle). It takes a bit of map reading until you find your way around, but the Old Town of Prague is definitely the "sight" not to be missed here. Great!

Too full of tourists. Prague is a beautiful old city - not just from its oldest part. I found the old town to be too full of tourists and souvenir shops and not very authentic. Old town was a bit disappointing to mee.

Lovely area, but heaving with tourists. This is a lovely area to stroll around, rather too much in the way of cheap souvenirs and the place was heaving, even on a mid-week day in April, so it would be awful in August!

Overall great place to visit. There's really so much to see and experience and absorb. And it's overall a matter of time, which this time we didn't have too much. There were two new things that caught my attention. The huge soap bubbles blowers and the trend of attaching locks with names and dates at special locations.And the Easter markets gave everything a beautiful and lively atmosphere. And the all those street performers and dedicated musicians too.

Well worth dealing with the crowds. This was my second time in Prague, and while only a few years have passed it seems to have become more popular, and with it comes larger crowds.However, I still found it to be a rewarding day. Definitely follow the crowds through the streets and take in the various churches, the astronomic clock, Charles Bridge, Prague Castle, and all the beautiful buildings. Just make sure you use one of the elevated vantage points at some point to really appreciate the view, and get a sense of how Prague and its districts are laid out. The Old Town Hall is a great place for this, just be patient as long queues are common. Alternatively, you can enjoy a similar feel and experience architecture of the same era - minus the crowds - in Bratislava, Slovakia. If you prefer a more manageable sized area and a less touristy feel then head south. I personally feel both are worth seeing at least once, and hopefully you have the opportunity to do so on a nice, clear day. :)
views over views. So many things to see, by feet, by bus or by an old vintage car, ours was a Praha built in 1929. 40€ for 45min Trip for the 4 of us was worth every cent.
Buildings Amazing. loved Easter Markets, found big price differences, didnt like the beggars, or tramps ratching in bins.

Really nice place. Very picturesque, nice place to visit. A bit more expensive for drinks and food than the other side of the river, but still pretty cheap. Were markets there selling food when I visited which were nice on the whole however beware buying from a food stall where the meat etc is put on scales. They will deliberately give you massive amounts and expect payment to match. I was handed a slab of meat worth 580 crowns (almost £20 of food with the potatoes I had too!) and they got shirty when I asked for them to take some back.Obviously, this was a one-off negative experience. I only gave 3 stars because whilst the place is nice, I actually preferred the quieter side of the city on the other side of the river.
Unforgettable. Very nice place. You must visit. Good atmosphere, and exciting architecture. I liked everything. It was full of tourist.

Must. This is of course the most visited place in Prague. Don't worry cause you will go by it whether you want or not, cause it's in the middle of Prague. It's beautiful. Try to sit in a bar, have a Czech beer and just look around.

Small, but charming. As far as old town is concerned, this place is not large, but it has little bit of everything, a Jewish quarter and old cemetery, Jesuit observatory and library, small gothic cathedral and old town clock tower.

Scenic but a tourist trap. The Old Town is very pleasing aesthetically, this is undeniable. As someone who does like to avoid other tourists, I found the area tedious after a while. Amongst the crowds are the people selling tours, pub crawls and the people hoping to persuade you to eat and drink in their restaurants. There is a market in the middle of the square but each stall sells more or less the same thing, beer, hotdogs or souvenirs. It is a must see area for its architecture but unless your happy to watch crowds and tour groups on segways then an hour or so is enough time.
Worth seeing!. The old town is lovely with all the narrov streets and small shops.The crowd of tourists is huge around the main attractions.

It's becoming Vegas. For those of you who visit the old town for the first time, you would probably find it magnificent, absolutely gorgeous; nevertheless, it would be a big disappointment for those who had visited Prague before. The old town feels like a big shopping mall where the buildings have lost their historical meaning and they are just part of the scenery to lure tourist to buy things. It wouldn't be that bad if at least these things are high quality items difficult to find elsewhere; unfortunately, this is not the case. There are gazillions of souvenir shops with very distasteful items; overpriced bad food and the usual brands that you will find in every corner of the world.
