I believe that some things are sacred, and at least the old town square should remain free of this stuff. Part of the magic of Prague is that it should make you feel that you travel back in time; it is difficult to accomplish this when all you see is present day mass produced garbage. Despite all of this, the old town is still beautiful.
Old Town Prague.. A must see. Beautiful city with so many old buildings and history. Streets were full of life and weather was perfect

Beautiful Beating Heart of Prague. If you are visiting Prague you'll inevitably end of in the Old Town and at the Old Town Square as that's where the tourism is centred. The Square and the Astronomical Clock is a must visit and you'll find a number of street performers and it's great for people watching. I particularly loved the old buildings and church. You'll no doubt find stuff to do in the square whether it's a gallery viewing, a segway tour or just a standard walking tour. There is a wide selection of restaurants in the Old Town but I'd recommend going somewhere that isn't on one of the busy tourist streets (I loved Mlejnice, for example). The Old Town can get very busy, especially at the weekends. I would recommend, if you can, to incorporate a weekday into a city break in Prague as the crowds are less overwhelming than on a Friday night through to Sunday. Although, the atmosphere at the weekend is electric! I can understand why so many Stag dos and Hen Nights go here.
worth to see it. i liked everything , in this city the time stand still and you feel like your connection with a real world is interrupted somehow

look up. Don't forget to look up, you will find so many great buildings and statues, a very clean and well kept city. Go a little away from the main streets and you'll find better food and coffee places at half price and twice the quality.
The Astronomical Clock. This clock is so intriguing. The Old Town Square is a great place, but the clock: to most people it is an enigma, research it before you go.

crowded but pleasant. A must seen place. Don't think that any traveler in Prague misses this square, the Astronomic clock, markets. restaurants and lanes which starts from the square. Pleasant place day and night/

SIMPLY LOVABLE. One of the most interesting and beautiful part of Praque which is really a lovable town. Stare Mesto is so alive, full of tourists and artists and if you are lucky, like us, you may enjoy a concert of classic music, at the square.Full of history, with fantastic buildings of great architecture and nice colours, the Astronomical Clock (lucly that we were there when bells at 12 oclock),the churches, the hourse-carriages,the market of souvenirs, cafe and restaurants, the narrow streets, all these, creat a fantastic atmosphere.Three times we visited praque, left full of nice memories and the desire to come back.
Old town during Easter. Old town is a beautiful place. It can be crowded around the hour as then everybody wanna see the astronomic clock.

Amazing, simply stunning . Prague is a lovely city, so romantic so beautiful. I'm totally in love with this city. The center is amazing, so many nice buildings, so lovely , full of life, so many pubs, bars and restaurants. A must do is to go up at tower, from up you can see the whole town.
So many things to see. Everywhere you looked there was something interesting. Go for a wander from the normal touristy bits. You'll never get lost - or not for long!
wonderful buildings. great, varied architecture The Easter market was fascinating with unusual gifts.Tthe view from the clock tower was breathtaking
Great way to start the trip at Prague. Arrived during the Easter break, placed was packed with all kinds of booths and entertainment going on.
Old Town Square. A pretty square that hosts several memorable sights, including the popular Astronomical Clock; which becomes animated every hour.

Astronomical Clock. It was really fun to watch. We did it several times but it was not until the 5th time that we caught the best part of the clock's striking the hour. Be sure to watch for the golden bird to squawk at you.

Old Town Square Prague. The Old Town Square is the starting point for all activities that you wish to visit. The Jewish Quarter is about a 5 minute walk from the square. It is also where the Astronomical Clock displays its beautiful characters and music on the hour all day long. The square is massive with lots of reasonable restaurants on its borders. I am including a picture of a church on the square that has a running video of Jan Palach, a 21 year-old martyr, who immolated himself in Wenceslas Square in 1969. The video is well worth the 45 minutes of time to watch.

Starting point. Old Town area is the nicest part of Prague. The Old Town Square (with its Clock Tower) as a starting point to the walk tour through the old streets, across the Charles Bridge up to the Prague Castle. You must be prepared for the fact there are many tourist all year round. The best time for visit is May or September. Beware of pickpockets. Do not take taxi close to the Old Town area. Pretty expensive. Prefer yellow cabs AAA Taxi or Tick Tac Taxi (white Audi 6 fleet)

Medieval heart of Pragueementary. feel the atmosphere of medieval heart of Prague - Old Town Hall with lookout tower, Astronomical clock with apostles. There were executed 27 of "Czech Lords" on 21.7.1621 . Very near is jewish town and Jewish cementery with Rabbi Loevi grave ( " creator of Golem")
Old Town Spring Festival. Sites and food were terrific. Definitely worth a visit to this awesome, historic city. Very friendly people and lots to see.

Easter market and many other things. Easter market is Czech traditional, so you can try Czech food (mostly 'kolbasa') and drink a lot of beer, which is really good. It could be great music and dances there too. Old Town is famous because of the Tynsky Chram (Church) and big clock. There are endless restaurants, coffee shops and a few quite good jazz clubs there too. You will not be bored! But be careful with pick pockets and sometimes not honest waiters in restaurants. It is always good to study carefully your bill and ask your waiter in calm, but very strict way, if 2+2 isn't 4.Old Town by night is beautiful too, so be prepared to walk around enjoying the view and mysterious lights the whole night. Prague's guides organize ghost tours, so may be you can meet one kind friendly ghost and tell your friends about. Don't miss it!P.S. I enclose a complete guide to Prague's restaurants. Old Town is quite big, so it is not possible to suggest one particular website

What a Beauty!. I felt in Old Town like in story for children. There is a lot romantic small streets, beautiful historical buildings, nice cafes and restaurants and shops. It is the most gorgeous city I ever saw!
Relaxing weekend break. Astronomical clock superb. Square was dressed for Easter plus stalls everywhere. Stage included local events such as children in national costume, great atmosphere

Crowds are unbearable. A Sunday just before Easter was a poor choice to visit Central Prague. The noisy crowds of tourists and young people meant that the old town square was near unbearable. There were so many people on the Charles bridge we had to elbow our way through. The city is still one of the most beautiful in Europe but is being ruined by too much tourism. We remember it from years ago and were shocked by the commercial changes. The main churches were all closed on Palm Sunday, even the cathedral so we could not see the famous Mucha windows we had admired long ago. Those who have happy memories of the Prague of 15 years ago should pause to consider whether they want to ruin the memory of how it used to be. Both Prague and Dubrovnik have become like Disneyland. If you want to go still go midweek in winter.
window shopping.. the need to carry and idiot guide to work out what you will pay,for this or that and will it fit the case,

wonderful narrow streets, beatyful houses. I could wonder the streets forever and looking up on all the beatyful buildings, churches, synagoges, restaurants, coffeehouses and all shops. Also just fun sitting down and look poeple passing buy.

Quintessential Prague. A must see in Prague - narrow cobbled streets, buildings haphazardly built right next to the beautiful churches, magnificent statues and the sheer beauty of the architecture. Go up the tower of the Old Town Hall to get a fantastic view of Prague and watch the Astronomical Click on the hour. Beware of pickpockets and "beggars". Many currency exchange shops with touts promising "no commission" - best avoided.

Beautiful Old Town. Beautiful old town and square. We loved it. Wonderful old restaurants, bridges, trams, we enjoyed traditional Czech food and beer! - What's not to love. The Old Square is slightly spoiled by repetitive (and not very good) buskers. St Nicholas's church on the corner of the square worth a visit. I attended a beautiful concert with brass and organ, but spoiled by the number of tourists filming it on their phones. It's a church. It's a classical concert. Switch your phones off.
Lovely place. The clock although very old was a little disappointing , the clocked tower well worth going up as great birds eye views

A Must See If Visiting Prague. If you are visiting Prague then you probably have this already down on your "To-Do" list. Its an amazing place and if you are going before the end of April 2014 or a month before Easter any year the Easter market will be in full swing giving a nice buzz about the place. Some really good bars and restaurants around the square to sit and enjoy the view from. The buildings are really nice to admire and you should definitely just spend 1 whole day roaming around the square having lunch / dinner / drinks and take it all in at different stages of the day/night. Its best to visit really early in the morning on a weekday (5am/6am) as its pretty much deserted. So if you`re having a late one somewhere in town or are an early riser then have a stroll through here as its swarming with people after 9am until late into the night.
the most beautiful city I have ever seen!. So much to do...Visit the leather coat and fur shop just on the main square! lots of Chrystal and jewelry.
Just beautiful. Very good for a scenic walk in the evening. The the river, the famous bridges and all the historic buildings with typical drinks and great food. Perfect for a short trip.

special. The old town offers many things to visit, have a drink , and all kind of shops.
The Jewish museum and synagoge is also a 'must'.

Marvellous!. That is definitely one of the most beautiful Old Towns all over the Europe. Leave plenty of time, because every little street in Prague has something interesting to show. I have spent all day there. I definetely will be coming back!

all the money. i dont have something to say. Is all the prague which is all the money.........
So beautiful and romantic
great place to see and explore. lots of individual stalls to see and places to buy food. Full of entertainment, bandstand,and music. cobbled streets so wear flat shoes ladies
Amazing old buildings!. Everywhere you look there are wonderful Baroque buildings of different colours. If you like history and architecture it's a great place to visit.

Guided tour. We were taken on a guided tour as part of our docking on our recent River Cruise. This place was extremely busy with loads and loads of tourists also being guided around. The buildings were very old and historic and the architecture was very interesting. We had to wait quite a while to see the astronomical clock which was very different. Lots of good shops in the area but we were warned about pickpockets although we saw none of this.
Beautiful!. The prettiest town square in the world! Absolutely beautiful magical town square. Quieter during the week.
beautiful!. don't go at the weekend or at high season (whenevr that is!) since it was even very busy mid-week in May.
walk the walk. the old town across the charles bride was defineately worth the walk,(we went over three times.)lovely buildings some nice bars and restaurants and some nice shops

Centre of any visit to Prague. Any visit to Prague, however brief , must include a wander around the Old Town (Stare Mesto). The area has plenty of shops, restaurants, historical buildings including the world famous astronomical clock and street performers. Not to be missed

So much beauty in Prague. We visited Prague with friends from Germany who also happened to be friends with a travel agent in Prague. What an awesome blessing! Jana, who speaks perfect English, took us all over Prague, seeing sites we would never have been able to see otherwise, all the while providing dialogue/explanations to thoroughly allow us to appreciate it more completely! The old town is absolutely beautiful. I had always heard Prague was the most beautiful city in the world & didn't believe it until our visit. Now, I'm sold!

A must.... You'll enjoy it. Great restaurants, interesting historical spots and real Czech atmosphere.Attractions^ St Nicholas Church, Charles bridge, the tower of the Old Town Hall with its splendid views, and so on...

charming. Beautiful buildings winding streets lots to see-clock worthwhile but generally just a nice place to be (very busy weekends)We wandered a fair bit and found a square with handcrafts and fresh market items but it was gone on the weekend (n_____republican square. Lots of restraunts have music in the evening and its busy and safe to wander. We were warned abut pickpockets so took precautions

Beautiful area!. We lived in the center of the old town square which was imo the best place in the city. Could've easily stayed there for the entire trip. Gothic building and narrow streets makes this a very romantic place aswell. Of course very touristy, but that didn't bother me much.

Fantastic architecture!. Lovely part of Prague. Go early to avoid the crowds. Lovely to sit with a beer and watch the world go by! As someone has put below, be sure to explore the side streets too. So much to see and do!
lovely area but lots of tourists. go early morning or later to avoid the hordes! the main square is nice but take time and go off the side streets and explore a bit.

Glorious architecture. Despite the crowds of tourists, it's a must see area with the most amazing architecture whichever way you look. There is an abundance of entertainment going on and lots of lively music. The clock on the hour is the focal point and a trip up the clock tower, partly by lift, gives wonderful views across Prague. There are many cafés and restaurants around the square and also some seating near the statue, so you can spend a lot of time just soaking up the atmosphere and watching the world go by.
Buildings and tourists. Nice buildings, also nice nightime lights and lot of tourists any time of the day. Souvenir shops and restaurants, cafes.
A Must to understand Prague. This is where the history of Prague lies. Stay here, eat here. Buildings, concerts, parks. It's all here. Best done on foot if you are able.

very unique, very busy place. lot of tourists, lot of street performances, you can easily stuck there just starring at place, people, architecture. in the tiny streets nearby you can still feel a little of the old ages. touristy but charming face of prague.

Photo opportunities every turn.. What a lovely area to visit with a photo opportunity at every turn. The architecture around there is amazing with cobbles street to top it off. A must see area to add to your itinery.
wandering through old town. the old town has no much history and character the old gothic building are fantastic just to stare at,you can wander round in circles and still see something different
Prague Lod Town. Lovely old town, compact, walkable. Lesser Town same, didn't need 2 or 3 day travel pass if hotel close enough to walk into town

Beware Of Orange coloured , NO Commision Money changes.. Lovely area just to wander around. We didn't book any tour but I think we found just about all the spots there were by ourselves.Be warned though about the money exchanges marked NO Commission. Especially one with an orange placard . Do not change your money there, do it at home or in a bank. I made the mistake of changing money there because I could not find a bank and I had left my money converter at the hotel. By the time I checked it out I discovered I was short of over 1000 Kroners. By the next day the only print left visible on the receipt they gave me was my signature...

Volume of people detracted a little from the experience. The old town area is attractive. Lovely buildings to see, some nice attractions like the clock and the churches. Was not really so much nicer than the rest of the city though. We spent our four day break wandering and 90% of the time it was quite peaceful for a city and we could take our time to check out the different buildings, views and cafés/bars. In the old town there were just so many tour groups taking photos by the dozen it was hard to get a moment to just look a things. The eateries and shops seemed expensive for what was available and it was probably one of our least favourite spots. Worth seeing I guess but doubt I'd bother going back.
Just keep walking. this was the advice we were given by a guide who told us all to lose ourselves around the streets and squares in the old town - good advice.

inevitably busy, but fascinating. it is inevitable that Old Town square, as one of the 'must see' places in Prague, will be busy. Crowds seem to gather particularly in front go the astronomical clock, so you need to grab photo - opportunities when you can. It was good to know some of the history beforehand, to make sense of the crosses in the ground, the plaques and the statue. There was a jazz band playing in the square when we were there which added to the atmosphere. There was also a guy creating huge bubbles that floated above the square. If you are keen on photography, take lots of pictures of the bubbles, as you can end up with some exciting and surprising images as a result of the reflections or catching them as they burst.

A victim of its own success. I haven't read any reviews of the Old Town - this just came up as an option after a previous review so I have not been influenced by any other opinions. I must say, though, that despite the lovely buildings, the place is spoiled for me by the complete sell-out to tourism. It's possible to have a world heritage, jaw-droppingly handsome town without turning it into Disneyland. Rothenburg ob der Tauber and Edinburgh are two examples - but virtually every shop in Prague old town either sells tat to the vast crowds of tourists or displays expensive brands which those tourists presumably aspire to. Yes, I am a tourist too, but not one who would ever return to Prague, which I consider utterly spoiled. It isn't a real place. There are no shops for the locals and most people you meet seem intent on separating you from your money. I think that if you want to see it done properly, head for Gdansk or Stralsund.
It's a must. Nice city center, perfect for walking and shopping, with a lot of restaurants and bars. Hoistorical buildings are astonishing.
beautiful. Had a meal in one of the street cafe's here, beautiful venue to have an evening meal, and great food to boot. STunnin g location

One of my favorite parts of Prague. Old Town always has something interesting going on. It's a great place to grab a bite to eat, look at the beautiful scenery and people watch. There are people singing, or doing other things. It was a place I would always come back to, to chill out and enjoy my time.

Amazing. This beautiful old square is a bustling center of tourism, history and food. Make sure you try the Trdol which are cinnamon pastries baked on stick over coals in booths on the street. The wurst is also delicious. You can climb the tower in the old town square but the lookout area is very narrow and it is often VERY BUSY and crowded up there

Lots to see. Prague Old Town is really interesting with lots to see, loads of restaurants and food stalls. Make the effort to go up the Powder Gate and/or Old Town Hall towers as the views are amazing.

Old. Town Square is the place to be!. We stayed within 10 minutes walk of the square. I think it made our weekend most enjoyable. There are restaurants, cafés, tour guides, live entertainment, and more. Best of all is the Astronomical Clock located at the square. Be sure to make the trip up into the tower to see stunning views of the city.

Best place to stay. This area of Prague is a network of narrow streets with many small shops and cheap authentic eating places. Stay away from expensive cafes in the square. Rule of thumb... if a beer costs more than 100Kns then you will be ripped off if you eat there.

things are looking up. The architecture is endlessly beautiful, but only if you keep you gaze above ground floor level. Otherwise you will see nothing but shop fronts and signs saying Tesco, Starbucks, MacDonalds, C&A, M&S ... and you will wonder why you bothered to come!
Astronomical clock. Like seeing the Apostles come out of the door of the clock on the hour, also live bands in the square.food stalls and local beer.
Easy Walking. Loved the vibe, river walks, great Czech pubs and restaurants.So reasonably priced too. Would stay in the area again.
Just beautiful we were there in February. So beautiful we went there at one point every day I still gave the musicians on a video on my iPhone I lived Prague and all it's sites
Medieval. It kinda gave me medieval feel and also the feel of the disney kingdom kind of fell. The weather I went in was perfect and the place is vibrant and beautiful.
The most beautiful place on earth. Old Town and Lesser Town are the most beautiful parts of Prague and probably the most beautiful in the whole world. All travellers should visit.

Unreally place . That's us really unreally place. All people must visit Prague , all is great!. Deep historical places.
If u want to buy chz granat, try to visit antiquarian shop, better place with reall granat and beautifull items!

Glad to be back after 35 years. When I first visited Prague 35 years ago I was struck by the fact that there was no litter and thought that this time there would be but NO.......everywhere is kept very clean.Some of the buildings are 700 years old and it was wonderful to soak up the atmosphere of the square where all those years ago the merchants and tradespeople came to sell their wares. This square was a meeting place for people coming from all over Europe and today it is the same....many different languages could be heard.The square is very large and in the sunshine folk sat around listening to the jazz groups and the singers while the children chased the giant bubbles from the street vendors.Surrounding the square are many cafe/bars providing coffees, teas alcoholic drinks and Czech food and one must take advantage of a few hours in the square before leaving Prague. We enjoyed the Czech beer and Tiramasu.....but it is more expensive to eat in these restaurants. the ice cream is to die for!Paryska Street has changed tremendously and is now the street of high fashion and designers such as Gucci, Prada, Dior etc but I was much happier discovering the little shops found in out of the way little streets

A great place. Everything was beautiful. You could hear musique of different types while walking. We took a small trip by the boat on the river. The main bridge was astonishing, and in overall the whole place took us to a different time in the past. I loved it.

One of Europe's finest .... A wonder mixture of old architecture and colourful buildings. There is always some sort of activity going on, food to be eaten, beer to be drunk. A great atmosphere, with great bars and beautiful surroundings. You could spend a few hours walking around the old square, having a beer, and marvelling in the wonderful architecture. This is the gem in Prague's very impressive crown.

Atmospheric . Aside from the great architecture the old town is a great place to listen to live street performers, people watch, whilst you eat local street dishes like their Prague ham, sausages, sauerkraut and beer combo! The hot mulled wine is excellent too! Watch out for pick pockets and annoying drug lads on a stag do.
Lovely area. Loved wandering around in this area, the small winding streets with their bars, restaurants and shops
Breath taking. So much there, so much to see, how could one place hold so much history and stunning architecture. 4 days there and it was not enough!
great !. the Old Town looks great, I just didnt like some old, bad looking sculptures that didnt match the rest. overall a very good impression
amazing. this has to be one of the most amazing old towns in europe everywhere you look you will be in awe at the sites steeped in history
Amazing coultures. When you arrive to europe, you should visit Prague especially Old Town. The architecture is amazing!

A walk through history. This is a place that gave me the feeling to be back in time and catch a glimpse of old great empires, architectural styles and ways of life.
Some of the places were to crowded for my taste, especially the Charles Bridge.
beautiful old town. The old town has lovely buildings. But I think there are always many tourists - you should have patience..

Good and bad. The square is quite a sight, even to someone who has seen ancient and medieval buildings around the world. There is a great deal to see and do in the square and the streets around it, but you have have to venture a bit further to find anything really local as the area is stuffed full of me-too restaurants selling goulash and various lumps of pig. Usual advice - if it has a "tourist" menu, it won't be much good.

Old Town. The old town is a lovely area to walk around--esp near the old town square (the wencelas square is referred to as being in--the new town--although that part was est in the 13th century). There are lots of shops--however they all sell the same tourist stuff--so after looking in a few one can get bored. Lots of lovely little places to eat though. stop in at the catholic church to see how ornate it is and look out for-the hanging man--a piece of art which looks like a real man hanging from a roof pole.
Romantic town. The old town is very good place to walk and see interesting places and buildings. Must taste the Prague ham, which is prepared and sold in the square.
Lovely old town. The old town in Prague is a lovely area to visit with lots of winding streets, markets and of course the town square and it's attractions. A must when in Prague!

Amazing architecture. Be careful not to bump into other people whilst taking photos of the fabulous buildings around this huge space; the colours, decoration, different architectural motifs...all wonderful. There are plenty of interiors to wonder at too, but it's great just to wander around the perimeter and take it all in
great time in prague. the old town is a lovely place to see buts gets very crowded as the day goes on cafes very pricey there

Lovely. A really nice town to go shopping, enjoy a coffee an alcoholic beverage. Always some form of entertainment even if its just the gold/silver men acting as statues! The Astronomical Clock is great to watch too when it strikes the hour!

excellent. all fabulous - a very clean area and so much to see and do - plus so cheap.
we saw as much as we could in the 4 days we had and would go back in a flash

Chocolate Box pretty. Full of fantastic buildings,cobbled streets ,trams and a very calm & peaceful atmosphere.
Take some good shoes as you will probably end up doing a lot of walking!

Very interesting. Many things to visit and really interesting
Maybe we need more signs in English as not always is easy to understand indications
I hate the "exchange" brokers on the street
Beautiful!. A good central place. Beautiful buildings surrounded by excellent choice of restaurants, shops and things to do. A little touristy but to be expected.
Beautiful.... The old town of Prague is really beautiful. Many things can be done on foot. Many attractions nearby. Restaurants, shops, etc. plenty. Simply beautiful.
beautiful. The sqaure is just simply beautiful! This word describes it the best. All the buildings and the whole atmosphere is very historical, it's a must visit!

Stepping back in time. Always love the towns where you feel like you've stepped back in time. Cobblestone streets, vendors hawking their wares (how do we think that happened before we had "storefronts?!?", street musicians & vendors. Prague is a wonderful example of this. Strap on some walking shoes, venture out & about without a strict agenda, and experience Old Town Prague! It's not something you SEE -- it's something you DO!
Walk around. I loved Prague. It is beautiful. Full of history and charm with people who are grateful to be free. It is a beautiful city. You will love walking in the center.
Lovely Place. I will definitively go there again, beautiful architecture and lots of restaurants and delicious foodBUT too much people
Unexpected beauty. The historical center, Modern art Musem? (Art Gallery), souvenir's shops, views of the Vltava river, bridges, Castle and city views, friendly atmosphere

Nice historic area. Nice historic square and medieval clock and historic buildings. Nice bars serving reasonable prices drinks and food with heated patios in winter. Great to relax and watch the world go by. A must when in Prague.

Gorgeous at night. We came into town late and found the square lit up, street vendors selling ham, crepes, hot spiced wine, We watched the clock on the hour and drank hot chocolate from a little store ($6... pretty expensive... then found some down the street for $2). A really beautiful town at night!
Nice place but too crowdy. This place has a really authentic Prague atmosphere, especially in the dark, when Tyn Cathedral is lighted up.
Visit the Old City. We walked for five days in Prague two days old city, clock tower fire, parking, concert Recommended,Check the scene subway outstanding
Nice place to have a drink and take it all in.. The service was not great at some of the restaurants in the old town square and not good value for money.

Essential visit. This is a delightful place to spend a few hours, soaking in the atmosphere. There are plenty of bars and restaurants, we had breakfast here early one morning when the square was much quieter and we had uninterrupted views of buildings and statues. Another visit in the early evening saw the Square much busier, with street entertainers and crowds of wandering visitors. One visit is not enough to this dramatic square.
Nice walk. The old town has a very distinct European Architecture, amazing area to explore, lot of authentic restaurants in the vicinity.

busy and beautiful!. A perfect place to sit and have a drink and soak up the atmosphere of a place which has seen such tragedy and history. A perfect place for people watching, with some lovely restaurants. I suppose February is out of season, and the square was pretty busy then, so it must be crazy in the summer. Brillaint buskers and a police presence which ensures you feel safe.
Not to be missed. Very pretty. Does not need an organized tour, just walk around and enjoy the culture. It's a beautiful place.
Not to be missed. Very pretty. Does not need an organized tour, just walk around and enjoy the culture. It's a beautiful place.

Picturesque Square in the heart of Prague. Fabulous square to stroll around in or sit and have a cocktail in one of the many out door bars and restaurants under the stars (and a heatlamp!) and watch the display when the Astronomical Clock strikes the hour. Take a walk up the clock tower for amazing views of the streets below.

Great out of season. Old town Prague is now quite justifiably a very popular tourist destination. It has a great ambience, but tends to be over-crowded. In February it was not deserted by any means, but queues were short and the main attractions were not so overcrowded that it gave pick-pockets an easy target.
A Must see. Excellent plenty of things to do and see. You must go up the tower of the clock as great views across Prague.

awesome. me and my hubby went on the 16th feb 2014 and spent most of our time travelling around old town lots of sights to see really good
.....a must see if in prague or as they say praha

Beautiful square. Great square. Plenty of aritists singing, posing as statues, bubble blowers and great way to see Our Lady of Tyn church and St Nicholas church. Beautiful architecture and lots of nice outdoor terrace restaurants. It has a great buzz about the place especially around the astronomical clock which is also in the square. Entertaining and great place to people watch.
wonderful. a really stunning area of winding streets,good shops,amazing buildings & lots of tourists!! great place to get lost!

Well worth a couple of hours walking. Even some of the tourist shops are OK! Just mooch along taking your time in the Owl Town. Don't forget to step off the main streets and have a look down some of the narrow side street - there are lovely little bars and cafes that are well worth stopping at.
Beautiful. I love old towns and This is really beautiful with wonderful architecture and character, the views over the river are lovely especially Charles abridge.
beautiful and magical. it's a wonderful place, full of history. The colours of the area change depending on the time of day, which makes it beautiful.

Excellent!. This part of town so as the rest of Prague is breathtaking! It seems you will miss something. There is always something new to see. Since it was the winter time, we enjoyed because there were not a lot of turists.

Charming. Prague as a whole is beautiful and charming - but this area is a must visit. Lots of shops, cafes, restaurants and street performers to soak in. It wasn't crowded at all in January (but it was well below freezing during our visit). We popped inside of shops and museums just to get out of the cold, and we enjoyed everything we experienced here.
old town. lovely atmosphere no dislikes great experience people friendly lots going on in square music and food venues nice to sit and watch the world go by with a coffee and local strudel pastry

Wonderful!. Old Town Prague is a remarkable place. The well-preserved architecture, the museums, music venues, street life, food, shopping, etc., etc., is vibrant and intoxicating. It is worth several days to take in. There was nothing I disliked about it. It was a joy to be there.

Our favourite place in Prague. This was just a beautiful place to visit!Great architecture, street artists, bands playing, bars, restaurants etc., but above all such a lovely atmosphere.We will definitely return!!!

Beautiful!. Absolutely beautiful, although very overcrowded by tourists. We were in and out of the old town for a day and saw at least 3 weddings. One of the most beautiful cities I've visited, but try and go either early in the morning or not during the tourist season :-)

My fridge magnet. With all my current travels the fridge magnet of choice is usually something that makes you think of the place e.g Rome Colosseum. This was my choice. The astronomical clock is located here and all the Christmas markets filled the square (January) it was almost weird once they had gone as it made the square feel rather empty. With the town hall tower to take in the views and the church of our lady before tyn also located here its got plenty to keep you busy. The architecture is enough to take your breath away. B.E.A.U.T.I.F.U.L. Hope this was helpful

Interesting and safe. Lots of fun things to look at and buy. In particular you should look at marionettes, Czech glass, wooden carvings and Czech garnet jewelry. All of these are unique in my experience.

Beautiful. This was a joint Birthday/Valentine trip and we stayed for five days. I believe an early-in-the-year trip has it's advantages, mainly that the city is quite quiet. Places like old town square and Charles Bridge must be a nightmare in the height of summer. So if there is anything useful I can inform as a result of staying here it would be...Research the public transport system before you get there. At first it seems a bit inconvenient and off-the-wall but once you understand it, it is straight forward. The only negative I would say is that ticket machines here don't have paper note or credit/debit card facilities so if you don't have the correct change you are forced to buy tickets from a vendor. If travelling late at night this can be problematic. Also make sure you have a valid ticket if making your way from the airport to Prague, if you get swept up in the flow of travellers and are without a ticket (which is very easy to do) you may find yourself being fined about £25. A ticket will cost you approximately £1. Travelling to places outside of Prague under your own steam is not for everyone. You have to be fairly inquisitive and tenacious to get anywhere (if you don't speak the language that is). We travelled to Kutna Hora by booking our own train tickets, which was easy, but we did have to endure some long waiting times due to my lack of understanding of their timetables.We also travelled by bus to about an hour outside Prague to a place called Lidice. The hardest part of this journey was locating the correct bust stop! But it did only cost 110CKr to visit this most emotive of places.I read a few times that the meals in the old town square were quite expensive, well in my short experience here I found that the open-air (canopy covered) areas were more expensive, but still quite reasonable compared to UK prices. Restaurants in the side streets seemed very reasonable to me. Of our four nights in the old town, we ate very well indeed, including a couple of drinks and second course for less than £10 per head.There are plenty of museums in Prague but I think the real attraction is Prague itself. The architecture and history behind it is fascinating and you are hard pushed to find a building that is unclean or in need of repair. There is little litter about and quite a high police presence keeping order, I think mainly keeping the many vagrants from causing unease among the visitors.The local authorities also do an excellent job illuminating the many buildings at night making them even more beautiful and magical then they already are. Finally, a vegetarian may find Prague a little irritating as most restaurants supply a feast of meats and dumplings on your plate as standard. I'm sure if I were to live there I would double in weight! Pork, beef and duck are on just about every menu. Speaking of food... Lunchtimes are great too. Goulash served in a bread bowl, which you can also eat afterwards is amazing value for money. You will not go hungry in Prague.I haven't seen it in summer but I can thoroughly recommend it as a winter destination.
Very pretty - good shopping for tourists. It's very pretty - exactly how you've seen it in pictures. Lots of narrow, cobble-stoned streets, lots of places to buy souvenirs.

Nice buildings but too touristy. We crossed Charles Bridge into the Old Town area several times during our four day stay in Prague.The quaint narrow streets were interesting and there was a wide choice of places to eat or drink, but although there were some nice traditional craft shops and galleries we thought that there were too many cheap tacky gift shops

Worth of seeing. When you visit Prague, you definitly have to visit the Old town. A lot of world-known monuments like Prague castle, Old town Hall and astronomical clock, beautiful Karl's bridge, nice souvenire shops.
Olde Worlde. Cobbled streets were a bit uncomfortable but added to the charm of this medieval place. Shop prices were surprisingly reasonable.

Great Site to Visit! - But don't get hussled!. We were in Prague for 3 nights last week and almost everything was just amazing. The architecture and history of the city seems to be neverending. Simply cannot describe the scene with words. The Old Town Sqaure is a must see attraction and you have to try the local foods and beers. However, on another note, I am hoping this review can save at least one innocent tourist from getting hussled for their Euros. Here are my two experiences that I have to share:Firstly, there are numerous exchange houses all over the city, but PAY ATTENTION TO THE COMMISSIONS and TRANSACTION FEES at these exchanges. The exchange houses display big posters which read "0% COMMISSIONS" but BEWARE!!! They cleverly hide the TRANSACTION FEES - which turned out to be over 20%!!!!!! Two of the guys in my group exchanged 100 Euros and only got back about 1,900 Korunas. The market exchange was 27.50 Korunas per Euro and we were given only about 19 korunas per euro!!!!! When you get back a large wad of cash at a legitimate exchange, you don't think they're ripping you off and you just pocket the cash without thinking twice, but BELIEVE ME THEY ARE RIPPING YOU OFF!! They won't tell you what exchange rate they are giving you unless you ask. They just tell you how many korunas you're getting. Don't be fooled people! We finally found an exchange that gave us 26.80 korunas per euro WITHOUT ANY EXTRA FEES - so don't settle for shady exchanges, there are good ones out there.Secondly, don't get scammed by one of the many street husslers who prowl the popular tourist areas. Under no circumstances whatsoever, DO NOT EXCHANGE YOUR MONEY WITH SOMEONE FROM THE STREET!! On our second day (we were a group of 5 people), as we were walking towards the old town square, a middle aged, middle eastern man approched us and asked us if we would like to exchange some Euros for Czech Korunas and he said he could give us a good rate. He was very warm and welcoming and seemed pleasant to deal with and offered us 30 Korunas for 1 Euro (the market rate was approximately 27.50 Korunas for 1 Euro). One of the guys in our group thought the exchange rate was good so 3 guys exchanged approximately 250 Euros and got some Korunas back at the rate of 30 per Euro. Not bad... and I jokingly said that the deal sounds like a good deal, unless the bills turned out to be fake. However the bills were not fake at all! In fact, they were real. But, there was a problem when we tried to pay for our bus tour. The lady at the counter told us they only accept kounas or euros and she didn't know what currency we were holding!!! The bills we had did not actually say anything in English letters. It was all in Russian. I googled the bill and found out the bills we exchanged were real indeed, however the pleasant man gave us Belarusian Rubles!!!! Exchange rate being 13,200 Rubles per Euro - meaning we were stuck with worthless paper. Nice...All in all, Prague was a great experience, but I had to share my story because it really made me mad!
nice place. great place, beautiful buildings. go at night and go to the top of the tower at the Astronomical Clock. great view, and top place for photographs.
goood and famous prague square!!. definitelly go and see this place :-) beautifull in the night and during the day too many people....

A must visit. I went to Prague and this is where my fiancé asked me to marry him. I would have been insane if I said no. This is the main reason why I love Prague and will forever love it. I enjoyed my stay here because the people around here would be so nice and helpful if they would find out that you’re engaged. We went to the Old Town to explore the place some more and enjoy. The place is full of old houses. The prices and rates on their food all around is very good, very afforadable.
Amazing!. The astronomical clock is cool! The entire square is lively and fun. Prague allows visitors to encounter rich culture and history. The Czech people are very friendly too!
Very beautiful, but cold!. You can do this in half a day. It was very cold, so we did it quickly! The clock is very beautiful! Every hour there is a little spectacle on the clock
Spoilt by touts. Way too many people touting for your business for tours or visiting bars. Lots of statue people, segways really spoil the beautiful surroundings.
Old Town. Lovely place, stayed at Hastal Hotel in the area and loved it...very central to lots of awesome sights in walking distance...just perfect!
Wow!!. The first time we walked into the old town square it took our breath away and that didn't diminish each time we walked through or around it. Everywhere you look is beauty.

Magical. This is the stuff fairy tales are made of! Towers, wonderful architecture, great food, and beers for 1.5 euros!
Could have a bit less shops for tourists, but it's amazing just as it is!

A must when you visit Prague. The Old Town will be covered in all travel guides to Prague. We used the DK Eyewitness guide, which has guided walks through the Old Town. You will visit the main square with the astronomical clock - be there a few minutes BEFORE the hour to see the display of the Apostles and the figures of Death, Vanity, Greed and the Turk. I recommend being there 5 minutes BEFORE the hour as twice we missed the display arriving on the hour. Also visit the Church of Our Lady of Tyn and the courtyard behind. You can climb the old Town Hall tower for views, but we chose to climb the tower of St. Vitus' cathedral instead.There is a beautiful portal c1590 at the House at the Two Golden Bears (Melantrichova Street, which leads off the Old Town Square almost opposite the Astonomical Clock).For a relaxing view of the Old Town Square have a drink in the cafe of the Grand Hotel Praha if you can get a window seat; we ate there one evening, had the steak and it was awful, so do not recommend having a meal there.But best of all, if you like Art Nouveau, do not miss the Municipal Buidling beside the Powder Gate. Go inside and have a drink / eat in one of the numerous cafes/ restaurants and do nose around, especially downstairs. The decorations are amazing, especially the light fittings in the ground floor cafe. Next time I go I will definitely book to go to one of the performances so I can see the Smetana Hall, although there are guided tours (twice a day in the winter, the first being at 1pm).
Breathtakingly beautiful!. Loved my stay in Prague and the downtown area is just so lovely and easy to walk. The food is delicious everywhere and the prices are good.
Great place to wander. Christmas markets were on and it is a nice place to just wander around and look at the shops. Not what I would call the fashion capitol of the world

Visit it in the early morning. Enjoy Old town square without tourist.. Come between 7-8AM or later in the evenings so that you avoid groups of tourists all around..Skip all Pizzeria and the most of all restaurants on the Old Town square as well.
Must-do when in Prague. Crowded, but still cannot miss a visit to the old town square in Prague with the astronomical clock, museums, departing tours and restaurants!

Perfect!!!. It was a wonderful experience visiting the Old Prague. I just loved strolling around the little sidewalks, admiring the view of all those old buildings and small shops. Listening to organ playing on cathedrals was just an amazing experience!

The pretty old town spot . Visited Prague last fall as part of out travel reunion. No doubt, this is a very beautiful city that earth ever have. Old structure are spread over and no body would deny that they are pretty. This area is touristy, then just blended your self as one of it, you will feel the vibrant of the city atmosphere. Use your comfortable shoes when scroll over the old town. There are many restaurant and cafe around, for some break with a glass if wine and light snack or for your lunch and dinner. Our experience teach us to re check the bill before pay. We found some of waitress are tricky, they put others bill on us. We have a bad experienced twice with the cafe around this square. One they put the tips at whatever value they want to have and in the 2nd cafe, they put others order to our bill. I don't think this accidentally. Just be aware of that. Another thing, be aware of pick pocket as this area so crowded especially in the bright sunny day. Unfortunately, these things quite a bit reducing the beauty of this city. However, don't stuck on that. Still enjoying the time walk around the old square, watching some attractions in the square and buying a souvenir for our love one at home, etc. Don't miss to climb the astronomical clock tower in the corner of old square to let yourself viewing the 360 degree of Prague. As a tourist, of course, its a must to come to this place with a camera for some nice memory bringing to home.
Atmosphere and Location. Central to many points of interest, Old Town has the atmosphere and historical highlights visitors have come to expect.

Great! A must in prague . We went to the top of the astronomical clock and had a fantastic view of all prague, also spend some time just walking arround the square, theres a lot of good places and stuff to see.
A top place in prague.

Beautiful. Beautiful square featuring the astronomical clock and wonderful architecture. Avoid eating here as it is pricier and not really better than elsewhere but you could treat yourself to a hot cherry punch and snuggle under the blankets and heaters in the outside areas at the cafes.
Smallish but very interesting. The astronomical clock is a must to see, lots of beautiful buildings, really worth to stroll especially on a sunny day

Beautiful. A must see! We visited the old town during the Xmas market season and it was wonderful! People from Prague are very welcoming and they greeted us with hot wine (hic!) during the cold winter.

Seriously touristy!. You need to really slip into the tourist mood to enjoy this, and if you do, you'll love it. Cobbled lanes and streets so busy in the tourist season that there's a permanent traffic jam of pedestrians, rows upon rows of gift and souvenir shops, ushers constantly trying to get you to enter their establishments, and huge tourist groups led by guides with umbrellas or funny hats frequently rolling past. But it all adds up to a great atmosphere, and the huge, lovely buildings lining every street and lane are gorgeous and romantic. It's a part of the Prague pilgrimage, and as long as crowds don't scare you and you don't mind being occasionally pushed by an overenthusiastic tourist, it's great fun.

My favorite spot in this old city. Walkable but be weary of pick-pocketers. I visited Prague when I was 15 year old, while it was still a Communist country. I've been there several times after, but it is mind-boggling to see capitalism at work and a free market system which means chochkies galore, over-inflated prices and crowds of tourists.
Busy but pretty. Quite touristy and always very busy but very pretty! Watch out for the pork stalls-tasty but very expensive!
Ancient beauty. A must visit in Prague.Main attraction would be the beautiful astronomical clock.Beautiful day and night
Loved Prague. Italian restaurant at end of square with medieval cellars was brilliant. "Manufacture" shop sells authentic czech products and wonderful wooden toys which our 2 year old loved.

Prague at Christmas. We spent 3 days in Old town at Chistmas time. It is a beautiful town and has many great shops and restaurants. We enjoyed several coffe shops . The Christmas market was good. The clock is amazing .

A must for architecture buffs. Wow, what a great place to walk round. Look upwards as you will miss a lot if you don't. Some extremely interesting places to see but worth going on a proper guided tour as you will learn more that way

Very nice area to walk around. Its a beautiful area to walk around. We went during Christmas season, so there were a lot of holiday shops, which were cute. We got ripped off by some of the food vendors. They charge by weight and really fill up your plate. We asked for less and they wouldn't do it. Be careful of them.
Worth Visiting. Many shops and great snacks on the streets.. Beautiful architecture and crowded place. A must see in Prague, even for a little walk around..
My favourite place in Prague. The Old Town is where you want to be if you are a tourist. There are heaps of restaurants and you are within walking distance of all the sites!

Time does wait .... a beautiful part of Prague, one just needs to centre oneself at the centre of the square and take a 360 deg view of the place - one cannot but get a feel of the history of the place. majestic buildings, marvelous architecture! .. definitely a must visit

Cool City. Prague is cool and a great place to hang out
Be careful of pickpockets and hookers who target single males and groups of males

Old town in January. There are still street musicians and performers, great restaurants, and incredible sights even when it's a little gray and 3 degrees C. The Astronomical clock is a must see. Also saw a nice art exhibit just off the square - Dali and Mucha in January 2014, I'm sure they have plenty of great shows year round

Fairytale surroundings. This is one of the most remarkable old city centres in Europe I highly recommend it. Some people might give me a beating about this comment but I rate Prague as more romantic than Paris!!

Amazing square. Go there yourself, there is no words for it. Eat at those stands in the square, they have the best ld Prague Ham and Kielbasa (with TONS of sauerkraut), and wash it down with the BEST Czech beer.

Best new years eve. We went to Prague city for new years Eve,if anyone is thinking of going next year we can highly recommend it . This is the third time we have been for new years eve and every time it gets better.May i suggest doing all the tourist things,but also just walk and go off the beaten track and get lost you will then find the locals bars and eat the locals food. New years Eve itself is brilliant a complete madness of fireworks let of in the streets,but be prepared and take very warm clothes.
Perfect week in Prague. This town is like a dream, wonderful sighseeing, people very friendly, good restaurants not too expensive, and Urquell Pilsner (their beer) remarquably tasty.

Old Town and Christmas Markets. We ended walking around Old Town twice! Once earlier in the day before we had dinner and then went back later at night. The Christmas Markets were being held and the hot wine was a great addition to the cold weather! Best slice of ham I have ever had. The Old Town has so much to see and going at different times of the day gave me some great photos!
Charming. beautiful & charming, must stroll through to see all the little shops! Wear comfortable walking shoes/boots

Great architecture. We visited for a long weekend and were both surprised by the architecture. The 'free' walking tours from the old square are not 'free' but it only costs what you feel like tipping.

walk through history. don't make plans, just walk and have a cup of coffee here or a dinner there, I recommend to walk across the Charles bridge to the Castle through Lesser town (similar but different)
Fantastic place. Unique beautiful old buildings, peaceful very clean streets, polite english speaking people!!!!!!!! The old Square is amazing especially during the night!
Beautiful. Lovely calm and relaxed atmosphere, not busy at all here in January. Lots of lovely bars and restaurants overlooking the square!

Beautiful place. The Stare Mesto is beautiful especially in winter with the Christmas markets open. There is such a great variety of things you can do there, wonderful shops to 'potter around' - especially the toy shops are amazing! There are many toy shops where you can get wooden and mechanical toys (instead of plastic and electronic) - definitely recommendable!

Traditional town. Atmosphere of the Middle Ages remains and is a city calm.There are many brick buildings and cobbled streets.There are a lot of tourists,I think security also good.There are a lot of cafe,so we can rest,a little high ?

Taxi in Prague. There is a 3-Day Ticket for the Public Transportation. You should buy this, because the Taxidrivers didn't learn about a good service in Prague. When we visited the Castle, we walked down and then, we planned to drive with a taxi to the hotel. We asked the driver, waiting downhill, about the price and we said , that we will have the taxameter.He demanded for a short way for 200czk. Then we decided, to book only the hotel limousines and the public transportation system

Walk around the back streets to get the full flavor of Prague. You must see the clock but do wonder around the back streets to get the full flavor of the city and escape the crowds in the square. I went during the Christmas season and it was beautiful!

Very old almost medieval. This square has a lot to see. My favorite here is the Tyn church, I visit every time I'm in Prague. The best thing about the astronomical clock is the skeleton ringing the bell

Magical. I was in the Square on Nov 30th for the turning on of the Christmas Tree lights. The markets were in full swing and the place was packed. What a fabulous atmosphere! hot wine, sausage and chicken kebabs, what more could one want?

So Rich in History and Culture. There are so many things to do and see in such a small area. There is so much history around and it's amazing what you can find when you just walk around. We literary spent almost the entire day walking around discovering things. It's definitely worth it if you come to Prague.
best town. the old town of Prague is one of the most beautiful towns that i have ever seen. everything is in walking distance and everything is amazing
Awesome. Just a beautiful old city with amazing architecture and ambience especially in the Old Town and with the Christmas markets (;last day was 6/1 ) Well worth a weekend trip

Amazing architecture!. The whole old town is just so pretty and gorgeous! Pictures do not do justice to this place. English is spoken everywhere so it's very easy to get around. I loved everything about this place... it is so artistic!

Simply wonderful. Let's put the picture together... After walking in medieval cobblestone streets filled with stores and restaurants you find yourself in an enormous square with amazing buildings and a great atmosphere. You get to see a church hidden behind some buildings, also you get to see a medieval clock that still works and that caused it's maker the loss of sight because it was so wonderful and revolutionary that prague's authorities didn't want him to do similar works in other towns, during christmas time you also see a beautiful christmas tree, free concerts and a bustling christmas market. That's the old town just great evertday.
Beauty with history. I liked every corner. The streets, the new year decorations, restaurants and so forth. The Charles bridge of course, town hall the astronomic cloch
Beauty with history. I liked every corner. The streets, the new year decorations, restaurants and so forth. The Charles bridge of course, town hall the astronomic cloch
Lovely. Great place to visit, in particular Xmas and New Years Eve. Lots of streets to explore and places to eat/drink. A must if you visit Prague.

Beautiful!. lovely, historically, for tours - not tooo expensive, to eat and drink, comparably to other countries in europe
perfect to sit on the square at night, drinking, can meet some chill locals

The centre of Prague. At Christmas this area is transformed with Christmas stalls, lights and Christmas trees. It is a magnet for tourists and a lot of fun with a great selection of Czech fast food, including hot dogs, carved ham and gluhwein.

Beautiful place with everything to find!. Old Town is full of tourist attractions, historical buildings, good restaurants, and shops. In some places it can be very crowded and very touristic with people trying to offer some tour packages or money exchange. The street are very old and beautiful.During christmas, it is also become more interesting with many christmas markets that sells plenty options of food

Stepping back in time. Amazing buildings everywhere you look. Lots going on. Stalls selling all sorts of things not just trinkets and the like. Because it was near Christmas there were lots of Christmas gifts.

Trip to History. Whatever you read in your guidebooks, when you see this place, you understand why architecture has been enchanting people for so many centuries! Old Town is beautiful in any season, but I especially liked it in summer, early in the morning, when there were not so many people, and you could just breathe in the history of those cobbles... :)
beautiful. The old town was amazing, the christmas stalls were out and the tree they had was really beautiful. We went to the theatre while here and saw a great show. People were so friendly

WONDERFUL XMAS BREAK. Wonderful places to eat and the service was really good. The local markets did sell alot of the same items and in the end we ventured away from this. But one thing for sure is the markets at night time with all the atmosphere is amazing.

Old and most beautiful. You get a real sense of history and the architecture is most beautiful. Well worth a visit but it must be said that there are lots of tourists and all that they "bring" with them.

Pleasant energy feeds your soul. ... just stroll and get lost in the narrow streets ..... enjoy hidden squares and bier-gardens, bier-cellars ... feel the spirit of the medieval times ... spend time with your friends ... hug your loved ones ... that is Prague :)
enjoy it .... bread with full hear ...

Favorite Area of Prague. My husband and I had the best time in this area. We were there during Christmas so we spent a majority of our time at the Christmas Market. So many amazing memories and gifts. Well worth a a full day and then some!

Walking back into history. Old Town is a quintessential part of Prague and is a must visit. It is right in the centre of Prague and has a lot of history dating back from 1500s and earlier with lot of historical monuments, souvenier shops and restaurants spread over a walkking radius of about 2 kms. It is just fantastic to walk on narrow stoned streets and is a calming (or sometimes tiring!) expereince in itself. While in the old town, try souvenier shopping for Bohemian crystal glasses in Blue Praha or Erpet or any of the local small tourist shops but do bargain in the smaller stores.Try the Gluhwine and local delicacies from the local street vendors as they are really good in taste.However, just be careful with your wallets and belongings.Great place though!
Old Town - worth a visit. Full of quaint streets and beautiful Architecture. Make use of the available guides to explain the history of the old town.

Lovely are to walk around. The Old Town is stunning and everything is kept clean and well maintained, at no point did we feel unsafe and walking around every corner produced another spectacular surprise. Guided tours are available, but you can even get some free.
Christmas in Prague. Loved this place. Very busy but no problems getting around. Not for you if you don't like walking but worth it if you want to see everything.
nice place, christmas time is avesome. Really nice christmass tree, also good grilled cheese and clasic "Trdelnik" sweet, if you come in winter durin christmass holiday its just perfect !!!!
lovely. Beautiful place, filled with people. A lot of shops and christmas was everywhere! The astronomical clock ofcourse is worth visiting its tower.

Fairy tale setting.... Prague's beautifully preserved old town has buildings dating back 800 years and is a wonderful place. There are ancient churches, elaborately painted facades, lots of little cobbled streets and much more. Don't miss the Old Town Square, with its renowned astronomical clock on the tower of the mediaeval town hall.
beautiful, cheerful and very crowded!. The heart of Prague. Full of things to do and see and very crowded... Attention to the street artists. Some of them are very good!
A little but of everything. Superb architecture, great bars and restaurants and often outdoor performances, this should be your first port of call in Prague.
A wonderful experience. Loved the buildings and the music in the square great fun to be had. We enjoyed a wonderful concert in the Castle. It was a touch of wonderland.
Nice square. Very touristy,but that is normal when you want to see certain things like the astronomical clock. Had a great Christmas market and we enjoyed a Christmas Eve concert.

A can't miss spot. The Old Town area is ancient and rich in beauty and architectural variety. A tourist center, it has many things to see (and is correspondingly overpriced by Prague standards) and is a delight to wander in, with charming restaurants and interesting stores as well as fascinating sights. Get a good guidebook to get the most out of your visit. Allow at least a day.
Great buildings and history. Loved all the architecture and buildings - the paintings on the buildings are extraordinary. Ensure you have good walking shoes on.
The Christmas market there was adding value!. The Christmas market added value to the beautiful Old Town center. a Very beautiful place to discover an just roam around.

So many great things to see. We really enjoy walking around and seeing the beautifully detailed buildings. Don't miss the Town Hall and Clock Tower tour combined with the Tower View. The tour is very informative and you can see the back of clock. Then go up and see the city from on high. Wander around and enjoy the many stores, churches, and museums. Great place for a day tour.

Wonderful atmosphere. Amazing architecture, indoor and outdoor bars and restaurants serving typical eastern europe fare, pork knuckle, goulash etc plus Italian pasta, pizza and Thai and Chinese (not tried).We were there for Christmas and it was quite magical with huge Christmas trees and thousands of warm friendly people.

Loved It!. The Old Town is beautiful and is exactly like the pictures one sees. Walking through the town there are many old historic buildings and in these buildings you have stores like Mango can you believe that.Every few yards you stop and look up and you will see spectacular monuments and statues.............wonderful!

Awesome Architecture and Beautiful at Christmas. The architecture in the old town is really cool. We loved wandering around the streets and seeing the different shops. There are tons of tourist shops and even a few Thai Massage/Spa shops (which I would not recommend as they didn't look too sanitary). It was definitely very crowded in the afternoon and evening and less so in the morning before 10 or 11 am.
Beautiful. Go around Christmas. Beautiful decorations everywhere. Plenty to see & do. Wonderful atmosphere. Unfortunately, you have to pay for entry into every separate site.

Great architecture. Prices in market quite high but colourful and brimming with food. Lots of concerts to visit at reasonable prices. we went to ST Nicholas Church and heard an amazing recital for organ and trumpet of Handel, Bach & Brahms

Magnificent!. This town square is a gem during christmas. From the vendor booths to it's gigantic christmas tree, it is worth to stop by to get into the festive spirit. The surrounding buildings and towers from midieval times emphasizes the mood and charm of this great city.

Fantastic Christmas Market- Bucket List. This is a must for Christmas Lovers - the magnificent architecture of the square and the fantastic Christmas Market was a winter wonderland. Great traditional dancing, fantastic medieval musi,c great food and drink at low prices. Much better than Munich and Regensberg Christmas Markets.
fabulous old town. wonderful cobbled streets; atmospheric; marvellous buildings; lovely little shops. many bars and cafes and street entertainers.

Beautiful Christmas Tree. We visited at night while the Christmas market was in full swing and the tree was stunning! It was crowded but with a wonderful Christmas atmosphere. There were quite a few stalls that all seemed to be selling the same items which were souvenir type items which was disappointing.
Worth a look. This is a lovely area, again lots to see and do. Go when the Christmas markets are on and you can just while away the time exploring and seeing the real Prague.

Historic and beguiling. Old Town area is the older part of two key parts of Prague,New Town is younger but is also very old.The Old Town area includes a wide range of historic grand civic buildings originally built for Theatre and local government use ,it also houses many fine baroque style grand buildings now converted into apartments or with hotel use combined with retail premises on ground floor.There is a smart modern shopping mall over 5 floors called the Palladium in Nemesti Square and a wide range of designer shopping outlets as well as tourist shops and smaller shopping malls.The area is well served by metro and trams.

Wonderful Old World Experience. Narrow winding streets (that you'll for sure get lost in), a stunning array of different architecture and buildings, and lots of great reasonably priced restaurants and bars. What's not to like about Prague's beautiful Old Town?!This is an area to stroll through, and to happily get lost in for an hour or two, and just to soak up the atmosphere.A bonus in the month prior to Christmas are the Christmas Markets in the Old Town Square (qv). Be sure to eat a Trldno (spelling?) pastry cone, and some of the Old Prague roast ham.

Must see in Prague!. Everything in Old Town was amazing, its really great for sightseeing and in the spring next to the astronomical church, there's a fare going on which they sell local Czech pastries!
Lovely. Full of Christmas markets and we even saw St Nicholas and the Devil on 5th December. Good central point to get your bearings and many small streets full of excellent shops.

Cozy!. Even when there are many people out there is a good atmosphere. The stalls are very cozy, the same with restaurants and places to sit down to get something to drink. They have heat lamps so it's perfectly possible to sit outside even when it's cold. You just have to remember to wear a good jacket, otherwise there is also fleece blanket available most places.

Beautiful but very crowded at Xmas!. Visited at xmas - the main xmas markets are in the Old Town Square. It was rammed!!! Walking like sardines down the small streets to get there. Though very pretty once there.All the stalls sell the same usual xmas stuff.Hot wine nice.Food - hot dogs reaosnably priced but the potato dishes were expensive, charged per 100g and they cram the food in. We paid almost £15 for 2 dishes.

architecture amazing,a must see. the history was amazing,truley stunning place to visit,its like stepping back in time,oldy worldy,traditional restaurants and cafes are amazing,soooo full of character
Beautiful square in winter. Beautiful square with music clocks, restaurants and nice Christmas market with food, drinks, music and gifts
lots of good restaurants.. lots of good restaurants and cafées. price level is good .............................................................................

Simply Magical. We visited during the 2013 Christmas Market, where the smell of hot wine and baked goods wafted through the air. The architecture surrounding the square is magical, the twin towers of the old town church look like something from a fairy tale, the astronomical clock tower has a great view over old town Prague, wasn't too impressed with the clock itself though. There are some great bars and restaurants around the square, a little bit more "expensive" than elsewhere in Old Town but still cheap by UK standards.

Ham on the spit. Christmas market is great no doubt about it ,I love it .you will too ,but I went to get the hog or ham at a stall bottom end of market near the restaurants.one plate 406 czk =£13;50 .daylight robbery and not cooked ,may look good on the spit but please don't waste your money,mine was unateable ,raw. , further on down towards the clock you can get a chicken on a skewer beautiful at half the price
So pretty!. Just walk about, take in the sights, and set aside a few days to do nothing but discover the beauty of old town and you'll have an amazing trip!
Magical. The best public Christmas tree I have seen. The atmosphere was magical. Great Christmas market too. Watch out for pickpockets or handbag snatchers though.
Real sense of history. Must see in Prague, especially at winter with the markets serving great food and drink, real carnival atmosphere.
Christmas Market. Lights very good as was food. Down side stalls were selling mostly general soverniers, rather than Christmas items.
FESTIVE TIME. this place is stunning for the christmas markets a must see in both day and night time the food is fantastic and the mulled wine a must!!!
Beautiful City. Amazingly clean, Christmas Wonderland are two words to express my views. Amazing buildings all decorated. People friendly. Food excellent

Relaxed. Typical old part of a city,not as busy as most cities , friendly & relaxed, hoping for snow. Roads seem safe for pedestrians mind the trams they wizz past at a rate of knots.shops & bars in abundance all english speaking & freindly. Worth a visit
Wonderful. Walking in the narrow streets in the night, crossing Karlov Most to Mala Strana when the noisy tourist crowd is away is an experience I suggest you. Prague is magic
Lovely. It's a big area and so many interesting buildings. Although it was crowded, I still liked it very much.

Very Beautiful.. I am not a good tourist but this area I visited often the architecture is quite stunning, and there are many nice place to eat, and have a drink. Even Star Bucks has discovered this area, however I avoided it because there are so many nice places for coffee in the mornings.

Sparkling Evening. Christmas trees, stalls selling delicious foods, pretty decorations, and the ugliest witches I have ever seen. Great for families and couples, students and shoppers. Not suitable for disabled travellers due to cobbled streets and uneven tiling on the pavements

A great place but very crowded. Typical tourist shops, but some very nice paintings and glass stores. Lovely Christmas atmosphere and full of stalls selling food, wine and gifts. It is very crowded due to the large amount of tourists, tour groups and locals all trying to get around.

Huge Christmas market. So much to see even in this small area. The Tyn church, the clock tower. The only bad experience of the trip was in one of the restaurants with outdoor seating around the square where we sat for about 20 minutes before walking out due to lack of service.

Very interesing and wonderful place. He old town of prague is very beautiful or I can say one of the best old cities that I've visited in my travel..a lot of beautiful streets ; lot's of tourists shops and a lot of checs street food..it's a big pleasure to walk aroud and see old buildings and nice shops..

A mediaeval miracle. To start with, I adore Gothic, I can't help it! There are numerous attractions, e.g. Astronomical clock, mediaeval houses, the statue of Jan Hus, memorial place of those executed after the battle of White Mountain. Don't always look on the travellers' tips, there are so many things to see! Almost every house is an exquisite piece of art! I highly advise to give it a go and just submerge into the place around you!
A great Christmas feel. Don't miss the Christmas market and celebrations in this square, in amongst the fascinating buildings and historical artefacts.

Nice place to see. This is one of the great places in Prague to see. Lots of great architecture, shops, and people. However it is tourist heavy so watch your pockets and know the exchange rate. The food vendors have some tasty food, but a chunk of roasted ham on a bun being $20 was not a good price (and they are all priced similar). Another woman selling gelato literally flattened the scoop, cutting the portion in half. There are a lot of shopping opportunities along the square, so look and be price savvy. Stop in multiple shops before buying.

Lovely square. We arrived here on the evening they switched the Christmas tree lights on, so it was rather busy! The square is very pretty with some great architecture to admire. Take time to sit in one of the many bars/cafes around the edge of the square, have a beer and watch the world go by. Maybe only 1 beer as the prices are more expensive on the square! The clock above the old town hall is fascinating to watch on the hour. I have been to Prague 5 times and never get bored of spending time in the old town square.

Christmas markets. This is full of history and at this time of year has hot wine to boot - what's not to like! Busy but great for strolling and be sure to visit the side streets for great bars and restaurants.

Lovely. Really charming, we were there over easter and there was a nice fair there with decorations all along the Old Square. There are more expensive pubs around the square but just around the corner we found a small old one with rediculously cheap beer, not that the beer isn't cheap enough in Prague! Prague in General is beautiful, probably at a close tie with Paris in my opinion.

I liked the outdoor cafes still open.. The square has attractions such as the Astronomical Clock to bring people in then the little cafes to keep them there for a while. Great mulled wine, the best of our trip, and people watching. Propane heaters helped chase the chill away. A very pleasant stop.
christmas market. lovely pretty market on, not sure if that was good or bad as you then couldn't really see all the lovely buildings and statues

Greate place. Great city, great atmosphere especially in Christmas time. Hot wine, allot of sweeties, music, dance ... all you need to endure the cold weather. Try to find accommodation in old city t enjoy all this.
Beautiful architecture. It was amazing to see how all those old building are still in perfect shape, specially after going through a major war.
City so beautiful. Take photos from the sky till the ground. Very interesting and beautiful architecture. But crowded attraction. Everyone should go to enjoy the beauty of this city.

A Stroller's Delight. As with any Old City in Europe, you must experience this one. The narrow streets hide delightful shops and restaurants. The main square is beautiful, especially at night when it is aglow with lights. The historical buildings surrounding the square are a must see in order to experience the Czech culture.
crowded in the plaza. The old town was crowded and not comfortable. I do understand why, because the city was just too beautiful so many people want to visit it!
nice and historic. Lots of history here. The restaurants a re a bit expensive, so just go a few blocks out and you are fine

Beautiful Christmas Market. Visited the Old Town in December and the Christmas Market was alive with people flocking to the different stalls selling so many handicrafts, food and drinks.Dont forget to taste their hotdogs, potato dishes and wine or beer.
What Praha is all about.. Depending on where you stay, it's hard to miss so we were always wandering through some section of Stare Mesto.
christmas market. were there for the lighting of the tree and the start of the christmas market bit overcrowded but the following day it was better with a nice athmosphere

Magical city. Old Prague is magic.
