You can visit anytime of the year, but for me the best time is either in spring, when in May many of Prague gardens are in full bloom and different concerts around the city, or at Christmas with market on Old town square. You walk around with a glass of hot glue wine in one hand fully enjoying the atmosphere around you. If you lucky enough and Prague is under a blanket of fresh snow, and you see the tops of its hundred towers covered in white, it looks like aFairy tale.

One of the Best!. We loved just wandering here....so many shops and restaurants, so many entertainers showing off their expertise and ability. Fun just to sit and people watch. The fabulous cathedral, the clock...so much to see and enjoy and for free!

Beautiful place to spend an afternoon. This old square is another nice area of Prague to wander and visit. The cathedral is stunning and the views at the top of the hill are stunning. I went in November and crowds were minimal which was really pleasant. I can imagine in the summer time this place wouldn't be as nice with too many people destroying the atmosphere a bit.
Surreal. The square, so old, and so clean, on a clear night amost seems surreal as if it were a Disney Epcot country. Follow the kiosks around and have some hot wine on a cold night.

A good place to wander. We had a great time wandering! Download some walking routes and remember to look up.Remember that the prices for eating and drinking go down significantly outside the old city!!

Beautiful. This is the Prague that has always existed in my imagination. Old, beautiful, and somewhat mysterious. Every building has a fascinating history, from Kafka to the astronomical clock. There are plenty of outdoor cafes and restaurants for you to enjoy a traditional Czech meal and people watch. Plenty of ghost tours and pub crawls at night too. Definitely not to be missed.

People live in Sculptures here!. Look at those buildings! People do live in Scupltures here. This is just as rewarding as an Art Museum. Wow! This surely beats modern Architecure. It´s a great place for a romantic stroll arm in arm, to find a restaurant to eat or for coffee or just a glass of wine. If you don´t want to shop, pick up your mobile and walk into some of the souvernir shops, particularly those with Glass Art and take some pictures as souvernirs. You´ll see things here you never will see anywhere else.
Gorgeous!. The city center, is beautiful and is tottally worth to spend hours... Love the architecture , stalls, shops, churches. The view from the clock tower is beautiful!

Huge and fabulous oldtown. I was impressed by the size of Prague's oldtown. Even 4-5 public transport stops away from the oldtown centre you can spot beautiful buildings, churches and so on. From now on it's one of my favourite oldtowns I've ever been. And I'm sure it's even prettier in spring or summer.

Picturesque and charming. Not to be missed.. A must-see for anyone who goes to Prague. Go on your own with a good guidebook, or take one of the "tips only" free tours. Enjoy the town square, the Astronomical clock, Charles Bridge, the various churches and the Spanish synagogue.

Such A Beautiful Part of Prague. You will love every part of it. From the Astronomical Clock to the old churches to the entertainersin the square. This whole area is so full of life. Sit in one of the outdoor cafes with a cafe latte, a beer or a glass of wine and enjoy your surroundings. There are so many unique restaurants and the food is delicious here and inexpensive compared to other parts of Europe. People are so friendly and helpful. Whatever you do don't miss this area, so beautiful !

A Fairy Tale City. My husband and I walked and got lost in the Stare Mesto many times. How else do you see a city? I loved the authentic feel of the town. The buildings reminded me of fairy tales from the Brothers Grimm. Just walking was an experience. Prague Castle was great! My only negative was the presence of graffiti. For some reason, I did not expect that.

Awesome-Quaint. It's happening here, NO RUSH and NO STRESS because the area is parked with tourists. This is ' Old Town Square', 'the Clock', 'Jewish Quarter' etc. There so much to see and do all in one place and jam-packed with tourists who are there for the same thing/soaking up the atmosphere.This is one of my favourite place in place and i always make sure that i visit once every month.There's Christmas Market in the square during December and people come from all over the world.Also there are lots of eateries, cafes, pubs, bars and restaurants in the area.English Pub: George & DragonCocktail Bars: Tretters, Bugsy, James Dean, Harleys etcRestaurants: Pravda, Nostress, Kogo (Havelska), Rybi Trh and much more

Beautiful!. Cosy but very crowded, even in October.Almost all the building you see are older than 600 years, and full of exiting histories. Very easy to walk around, with lots of small shops, and splendid restaurants.Went for a sightseeing by bus and boat, a splendid way to see most of the sights, without getting sore feet, and at a very low cost as well. Should have more that 4 days to explore this lovely city, so will have to come back again, soon!

Stare Mesto. I spent hours wandering through the old town. Buildings were fascinating, cafes were excellent, people were friendly, what more could you want. It is full of beautiful architecture and you can let your imagination fly.

History all around you. The Lesser Town (Mala Strana) where Prague Castle is located has many attractive but when you look for History the Old Town is your place. From the Old Town Square to the Jewish Quarter everything there send your mind some centuries back in time. A real must-visit when in Prague.
I like it. When I visit old city of European countries,I can feel 19th century.But in praque,I can feel 18th century and the size of old city is rather wide. This is why I like Praque.

A Medieval Experience.... Setting with buildings from the Medieval times, there you will see the Astronomical clock and Old new synagogue. There are 2 main squares, Wenceslas Sq and Old Town Square.Walk anywhere within these 2 squares to absorb the history of Prague, view the Barouque and gothic buildings. A beautiful sight.

The Golden Town. It tells a 700 year long history expressed in a wide variety of architectural styles. From romanic churches to gothic and baroque ones. From rococo, to neo classicism, historicism, Art Deco, Art Nouveau. Well renovated after the negligence of the communist regime, Prague is just a gem. We walked around with our necks stretched up analyzing and enjoying the buidings and their integration into a wide array of forms and shapes which create this unique urban togetherness.

Beautiful architecture. We visited Prague for 3 full days in mid November 2013 and our hotel was in the Stare Mesto district. Unspoilt by war (in the last century or so at least) this district is chic full of well-maintained 19th century architecture, often reminiscent of parts of Paris. While there are notable museums and other attractions easily visited in Prague (enough for a 3-4 day trip), just wandering around the Stare Mesto is worthwhile in itself, dipping in and out of cafes, bars and shops and soaking up the atmosphere.

Great sights. although not high season which was maybe a bonus it was ideal for wandering around at our own leisurely pace stopping when we wanted and browsing ... the sights were both stunning and spectacular ...the architecture was stunning and although was not my first time in prague but I appreciated it this time as I meandered around a my own pace .

Great sights, but be prepared to walk a lot.. Great historical sights, tourist concerts short and not as good as national opera and concerts (cheaper, longer and better), shopping is better not near the main square (factory store's cheaper), taxis may cheat you so it's better to walk or take the tram, check your change and use local currency, watch out for pickpockets, need to pay for toilets or go into restaurants, but food is cheap.
very beatiful. very interesting. different options. walking tour.amazing view.can´t go to Prague and leave this behind

Old Town Square, Prague. A must to visit both during the day and at night. During the day there are always street attractions, lots of fresh made sausage, ham and tasty treats. At night its lights and activerestaurants with the best and additional charge seating on the square to watch all thepassing tourists.

WOW!. All i can say about the Old Town Square is WOW! It is such a mish mash of architectural styles that in another place would be dissonant but here it works! Where to look first? Or do you just want to people watch in a cafe or stand around the Square and marvel at it all? And the entertainment on the square: do you go to the food stands first or watch the various performers trying to make a go of things in the square? Seeing the Old Town Square at night was dazzling, even better than day time. And how could you miss "The Show" at the Astronomical Clock in the Old Town Hall? A little hokey I thought and I avoided it for as long as a could. it is a reconstruction of a clock that was installed here in the 1400s and must have been a marvel of its time. Don't blink! Once Death tips his hour glass and sounds the bell, doors open with the 12 Apostles parading by seemingly acknowledging the tourists and when the cock crows, it's over!

Beautiful. Well worth a visit. Its difficult to know what to look at first, a feast for the eyes. May be don't eat and drink there, if you are visiting on a budget. Or may be just for a one off treat.

Such a beautiful place. I love Prague. The Old Town is one of the finest I have been to and the architecture makes it so pleasing on the eye. I love nothing more than walking through it's narrow cobbled streets, for hours on end, admiring the buildings and finding secluded courtyards and little squares, which present surprise after pleasant surprise. Whilst the cobbled streets can prove tricky, at times, Prague is safe and makes for a wonderful walk, with so much history and tradition on view, around every corner.
Splendid architecture and winding streets. We particularly enjoyed wandering the streets of the Old Town with breath-taking views at almost every turn.

Nice to see and close to Wenceslas. Its a nice enough part of Prague to see but is abit ruined with the vast number of Souvenir shops. Just keep walking past New Yorker (on your right side) and you will find yourself in Old Town

Beautiful Square. Had a delightful time in Old Town. Besides visiting the cathedral, and the Astronomical Clock, we visited the Jewish quarter and its synagogues. Was quite interesting see a Chabad Kosher delivery truck. Also enjoyed a relaxing coffee at Starbucks.
I Only Saw It At Night .... But it was beautifully lit up, the food in the square was amazing and all the shops are open til late every day so there's plenty of shopping opportunities.

Must visit!. in each corner of prague you will find a new thing to see!Old town can be good starting place to discover old prague!From here you can get to Charles bridge.or if you are after shopping you can go to Pariszka street for shopping!But of course clock tower is the main thing to start for all of this things!

Simply Amazing. Prague is the most beautiful city I have ever visited without any doubt whatsoever. The Old Town area is just amazing. You have to go. If you don't have Prague on your list of places to visit in your life, put it on there, because it's a must-see place.

beautiful but tourist central. There's no getting away from it, the old town is spectacular - easily one of the best in Europe. But there is also no getting away from the fact that you are surrounded by tourists from every corner of the globe, groups of people following someone holding an umbrella or sign. Restaurants and bars are hugely over priced and of very varying quality - mostly dire. Visit the beautiful churches, admire the architecture, but escape elsewhere to eat and relax.

Interesting walk. We were lucky to have a farmer's market going on, with lots of vendors of food, produce and crafts. Even without the market, the clock tower is a must-see, and there were a number of street artists - mimes and musicians - to keep you entertained. No need to go to pricey restaurants, as there were several food stalls, but beware of the vendors selling pieces of ham off the rotisserie. The ad suggests a reasonable price, but this is by the 100 gram unit - then they try to sell a huge piece for $35 or so. I saw several tourists getting ripped off this way.
beautiful. visited in both the day and night. loved the historic building and great atmosphere. it was busy but nothing too bad that we couldn't enjoy just walking around

Great during the day for shopping, be careful at night.. Lots of shops and places to eat, entertainment and also access to Charles Bridge. During the day lots of people, just watch your pockets and valuables. At night you get hassled a lot to buy drugs, visit strip clubs and things like that, so just be careful. Lots of lanes and Alleys, so easy to get lost at night.
HIstoric site worth a visit. Despite all the tourists (like us!) seeing the vast cobblestone square with only pedestrian traffic was great. A must see.
Amazing building. Really impress with the uniqueness of the building, worth to visit day and night. Always crowded with many tourist, must visit spot if you are in Prague...
Visit. The old town, the Castle, the Church, the moll Palladium, the opera, te municipal House for the concert, the Karlov most.The town is wonderful

Great old town. Excellent old town although it can be a bit difficult to find stuff, but maybe that is just me and my navigational skills. there are many historical buildings with all kinds of architecture and plenty of streets to wander around. You will find, places to eat, drink, sleep, shop, snack. But it's usually busy with tourists.

memorable. We walked from Charles Bridge. It was a most interesting place, full of tourists, young and old. We sat in one of the cafes fronting the astronomical clock to enjoy the scene. Drinks were affordable. We had a glass of iced coffee for 2 euro. In the large square towards our right, a live band was playing on the stage. People of all races could be seen here. A must-visit place indeed! Horse-carriage riding was rather popular here.Cab drivers were rather difficult to deal with. They would go only at their own price. No using meter here.

Beautiful - everything you want from a historic city center. I liked everything - the shops, even the souvenir shops, lots of specialty shops, a plethora of fine restaurants, all of the booths with Czech food and drinks, and really good Pilsner beers.

Something for everyone. Ideal tourist walking spot.. With its size and many paths, there's something for everyone such as: cafes, restaurants, stores, food vendors, photo ops etc. It's also an ideal place to just walk around as a tourist and see what tickles your fancy as it is connected to quite a few of the other tourist attractions. Some of the winding lanes/streets may get confusing after a while, but the most important thing is you're getting 'lost' in a controlled environment where there's still a lot of tourists and shops around (as opposed to accidentally walking into a deserted dark alley and it's too late).I strongly recommend having a cup of coffee with a friend in one of the many cafes/restaurants by the side of the road. It'll give you the opportunity to people watch, soak up the energy, and enjoy the architecture all at the same time.
old town ...........young dummies.......... did not like this too young and dumb for us we left as a family and they still would not leave us alone...........

A MUST SEE SQUARE. A huge square with many attractions, restaurants, shops, tourists ... My advice don't buy or eat there. Only watch because the prices are too high and the service is low, that's why you don't see local people. For eating, you may check Prague 3 & 4 areas where the rates are much better. Just follow the Green logo of the small restaurants

happening place. its the centre of town, so old so cute, you have to sit in one of the cafes and enjoy the spirit of the place and so many old buildings in all styles of architecture Baroque Gothic etc and the amazing Astronomical clock,,, and its tales .

beautiful little streets. Gorgeous architecture and monuments spread throughout the old town.The only downside is that tourists are everywhere. English and other languages were more common than hearing the Czech language but this is to be expected for a major European tourist destination.

Well worth a visit. If its your first time in Prague it would be a shame if you didn't visit the old town' especially the old town square. It's got a nice atmosphere, an amazing clock and lovely buildings.

Magical. This is a magical historic place. Walking across the George Bridge is like walking back in time. Old town is filled with cobble stone streets, and multiple nook lined passage ways lined with little bars and restaurants.

Designed for tourists- about a thousand years ago. This is the ideal tourists walking city. Turning every corner brings a different view of either winding streets or lovely squares. its flat and little in the way of traffic in the centre. Rather a lot of souvenir shops around the Charles bridge and their must be more restaurants per square mile than any other city- but thats not too bad a thing!

The most breath taking old city in Europe. The whole area is beautiful and lively and a lot of shops and some
Of the most beautiful castles and old building are on this side of town. The square is crowded in the evening with a lot of shows to entertain tourists and good restaurants around and most of hotels and shops are around here.Such a beautiful place.

Best part of the city. I absolutely loved the Old Town and especially the Old Town square, its stunning both in the day and at night. With the Astronomical clock and lots of detailed architecture. Lots of bars and restaurants and streets leading off the square to other parts of the city. It is definitely worth a visit at night also, as it is even more stunning lit up.

Prague re-visited after 44 years. I always had great memories of a visit to Prague 44 years ago. It was even better now!One of the first things which struck me was the cleanliness of the streets which is probably enhanced by the fact that it is forbidden to smoke nearby public transport etc. On smoking, it was also very nice to be able to leave shops, buses, trams without being obliged to inhale cigarette smoke. The only minus would be the restaurants in touristy areas where one has to watch out for add-ons to the tab such as 'couvert', offerings of bread and butter which they then charge you for. In quite a few cafés and restaurants I noticed that the 'smallest' beer is often not the cheapest! Traditional restaurants seem to offer meat, meat and meat with very few vegetarian options (fried cheese and pasta). Luckily, we discovered there are many Asian restaurants where it is easy to eat vegetarian.Public transport is cheap although it is very easy to walk everywhere in the city centre.

So different!. So dark, so gothic, so different from every other city I have ever visited. Walking in the streets of Prague travels you in time. You can easily imagine yourself living in the 15th century, just with more tourists around you. It is indeed a very touristic city, but you can find yourself alone living in a dream of the past, provided you are willing to walk away from the basic and well known monuments.
Wonderful. Fabulous architecture; fabulous views; wonderful area to walk around, especially crossing the Charles Bridge. Also liked the Kafka Museum; they created the right mood for him.
Awesome. We were very surprised at how cool this place is, a def must see if you in Prague!!! Lots of shops and restaurants close by too!

Old Town Square - the hub of the city. A beautiful old square surrounded by the most beautiful architecture. I never tired of it and whatever I did in my 3 day visit I always ended up in the Old Town Square. The Astronomical clock draws large crowds particularly just before the hour chimes. There are street entertainers dotted around the square, bands, artists etc and it is the focal point of the city. It seems to be busy day and night. During the day there are street vendors cooking and selling the most delicious food. You can take a horse and carriage ride. You can join a segway tour, and a lot of the guided tours start out at the square in the morning, as do the ghost tours in the evening. The square is surrounded by hotels and bars with outdoor seating areas. They are geared up for the cold weather with covered seating areas and perspex sides and they have patio heaters to keep you warm and blankets to keep the chill off your legs. Try the delicious hot wine laced with cinnamon. It has to be said however the prices to eat and drink in the bars around the square are quite pricey. But it has to be worth paying a premium price to soak up the atmosphere of the place. Typically a beer will cost you around 200 czech crowns. A coffee will be very similar. There are a couple of places that offer cake and wine for 150 czech crowns. The nice thing about Prague is that nothing is very far, with the exception of the castle. From the Old Town Square you can walk to the Charles Bridge, about 5 minutes, Wenceslas Square is less than 10 minutes away. The Jewish Quarter is less than 5 minutes. You must go to the top of the clock tower as the views are spectacular. There are lifts to take you to the top, it is a very long way if you walk up!

Cozy. We visited Prague during low season, so I guess that´s why we can call the Square "Cozy". I belive that the Square can be more popular during summer. There were vendors of food and drink and the fires was cozy in the evening. We listened to fantastic street musicians, both at daytime and late in the evening. There are many restaurants and pubs to choose from, if you want to stay for lunch or dinner.

Worth the trip.. Busy. Very busy. I came during the low season where the weather was cold and rainy. If you want to catch the square empty, I highly suggest going early in the morning. Be ready to eat from all the street food vendors, and they are delicious!Tip: climb to the top of the clock tower. The 360 view of Prague is breathtaking, regardless of time of day! Enjoy!

Don't miss. A beautiful centre of town with wonderful architecture. The clock is a must see if only for the detail. If you have a good zoom on your camera check the date aspect of the clock. And try and be there as the clocks strikes the hour so you can see the animation features. A wonderful place to stroll thru. Lots of people traffic

Oh. just lovely. Svejk-inspired cuisine is just a killer (they served a half duck with some piles of boiled red and white cabbage for a single person). Beer selection is much poorer than one would expect, you have to get lucky to try the better brands.The Old Town is just lovely and everyhing is in a walking distance, no public transport is needed.

Disappointing after all the hype.. Be prepared for the carnival atmosphere of the place. This place is a zoo of low talent performers and folks painted silver posing for money. There are a few talented musicians that deserve tips, but watch your pocket books and wallets.. pick pocket heaven. Still upset at all the graffiti on all those historic buildings. have they no shame?
Old Town and Astronomical Clock. A must see! LOTS of stuff to do and see here. Recommend having a cappuccino and people watching before or after you visit both churches and the Jan Hus memorial.

Hustle and Bustle. This is where you must head to first and move on from there.It all happens here. Shops, restaurants, bars, street entertainers, singing, dancing, crowds of tourists craning their necks at the astronomical clock on the hour every hour, tour guides clamouring for your custom. Stalls with local delicacies of all descriptions from hot Czech sausages to sweet rolled pastry covered in sugar and sweetly flavoured. The sounds and smells provide a boost to the senses that the eyes can behold whilst also taking in the buildings which contain so much history. You will pass through the Square everyday and will always see, hear and smell something different.While you are there take a trip to the top of the astronomical clock tower which provides stunning views of Prague and the surrounding areas.

Scenic and interesting. Lots of scenic buildings and history in this area. The market stalls selling food were nice, as was the presence of lots of musicians. Well worth a visit and no cost other than what you want to spend when you are there.

Magnificent Outdoor Museum. Basically Prague is just a huge outdoor museum. The architecture of the building alone makes it worth going, even if you never go into a museum. Thanks to Hitler just taking over the Czech Republic and them surrendering without a fight, the beautiful city of Prague was spared from bombs. Hardly anything was destroyed, making this one of the most beautiful cities in Europe. Seriously, it beats even Paris.

The Center of the World for Me. We have been there dozens of times - usually more than once during each trip - and it always impresses. It is historic, alive and exceptionally photogenic! The Old Town Square's beautiful Renaissance architecture around the huge square has been lovingly restored and masses of people cannot get enough of it, enjoying the cafes, restaurants, street performers or just strolling. We will be back.

great. Fab to walk around loverly market there just beautiful!!! Nice restaurants around great history and souvenir shops!!! Back streets great to explore!!!!!A whole lot to do there highly recommend!!!!

Favourite place in Prague. Absolutely stunning place. The anatomical clock is fun to watch on the hour every hour (huge crowd almost always). There's almost always some music or other entertainment going on in the square. Lots of food in and around the square, short walk to Charles Bridge - what's not to like??

Magic. I don't know why but there is something very magic about the old town. You just feel like you have been transferred to another era. The colors the sky gives to the square create this unique atmosphere which I haven't seen anywhere else. Truly romantic.
Nice town. Magic town with great atmosphere where it is relaxing to walk within the streets between nice buildin and church, castel,...

Old TOwn. This walk about was a great walk back into history. Definitely put your walking shoes on for this one but it is very well worth it. We had a friend from the area who could explain some of the buildings and sites, which we found much more relaxing then being part of a larger tour group. There were many local artisians as well as on the weekend many booths offering the local foods and beers (which you just have to try). Prices for the foods and even the local arts were very reasonable.

Wonderful day or night. We had a late snackr at a cafe in the square. It was chilly out that night. The cafe provided outdoor heaters and fur throws to place on the seats. It was so cozy. Great place to watch people and see the Astronomical Clock. So much fun!!

Prague and its beauty. I just can tell you - visit this city, you won´t regret it!It´t just beautiful to be there, and you can walk with open mouth (and eyes) and see all this beauty, that came back after the fall of the iron curtain.I love this city, and every time of the day enfolds another atmosphere - like in every city - but Prague is special in every case.
Third time's the charm. This is my 3rd visit to Prague and I continue to enjoy the city. Lots of fun things to see and what a great city for people-watching.

A fascinating place. Any visitor to Prague will be pleased to visit this area but watch out for pickpockets in what is always a crowded area. See my Charles Bridge review for tips on pickpockets. Always wear a belted wallet, or one attached to your belt. Ditto mobile phone.

Spectacular Town Square. What a wonderful vibrant medieval type atmosphere there is in the old town square - spectacular architecture, lively entertainment (buskers, concerts & presentations), numerous restaurants, food stalls and bars and a lot of people watching!
Even though it's crowded, it's worth it. It's no wonder there are crowds. It is probably the most beautiful and magical town square I have ever seen.
this is a beautiful city. the architecture was amazing and has lots of history. it was also very clean and cheap. it could be very busy at a weekend with stag partys.

"Town" is The Correct Name. Old Town doesn't feel like a city; it feels more like a large "Town". All of the sites are nestled close to each other and make for an easy walk. You can walk the length of the Old Town in just a few minutes, from the Charles Bridge to the Powder Gate. We think it is like a fairyland with all the wonderful old buildings and other structures. Bring your camera and have a field day!

beautiful square - but dont buy the ham!. the square is beautiful. the street entertainers are great and the atmosphere is lovely. do not buy the prague ham from the food stalls, this is a rip off. price is per weight and they try and give you lots and charge you a fortune. the restaurants are better if you walk away from the square down the little streets. you will get better quality and cheaper food away from the square.

VERY FINE HOTEL. Cathedral Music Performances, Personal Tour of Prague (2-day), outside Prague day-trip to Cesky Krumlov, hop-on hop-off trip around Prague, the Charles Bridge & Castle, and much much more.

Awesome places to be hanging at day and night.. That's a most visited old town during noon or evening. I was passing through there before heading to Charles bridge and vice versa. As I know during evening, there was street art performance at the square. You will see different peoples perform at some other day maybe.

Fantastic architecture. amazing place and not so spoilt by graffiti like much of the city, fabulous buildings, street markets, entertainers and bars to sit outside of whilst sipping local Lager and people watching, a bit of a Christmas market feel
Beautiful.... Really, really beautiful city and worth the effort, take comfy shoes and a health thirst for cheep beer and well priced food.

Something for everyone. so much fun to walk around and watch all the different entertainers, sample all the food vendors, go for a ride in a carriage, go to the top of the clock tower and enjoy the spectacular view, and have beer!

Explore to the fullest. Old town square and roads nearby encapsulate most of Prague tourist attractions. It gives you a taste of how mrkets were hundreads of years ago. You can spend hours there or visit several times nd still discover new things.

Beauty mixed with history. One of the most beautiful city I've been too. Just an amazing architecture, lots of nice cafes with some nice atmosphere, bars, pubs etc. Huge number of amazing churches - though they are full just of tourists instead of the Chech.It's just getting too crowded sometimes. During the nice weather it's even hard to find a place to seat so you feel like in a shopping center:-)You need long days to see all interesting points of the city. I will be back for sure since I have spent there just two days and I feel like it's not enough

A little compact gem. My wife and I loved the architecture, atmosphere and the bustling activity of this area with plenty of seats to have an impromptu bite to eat on the move and plenty of bars to taste the well-known brands of Czech beer. There are a range of tour guides each day and amazingly they are free and you just make a donation at the end. This was an inexpensive way to undertake a not-too-strenuous, interesting walking tour of the area.The astronomical clock was a bit of a let down having waited twenty minutes for it to do its thing but it certainly is a novelty. If you are tempted to buy garnets in Prague go to the shop near the Tourist information centre because you will also get a certificate of authenticity.
Magical Place. The Old Town feels like Magic, making Prague the best city during my european trip. If your going, stay there
Old Town Square,Prague. Easily one of Pragues most popular attractions.Dont miss the clock changing or a seat in one of the bars around the square and just relax.
Amazing. At first I was disturbed by the throngs of tourists and the cheap stores, but the beauty was just overwhelming to the point that I actually had chills looking around -

Unchanged surroundings. Yes, Prague is overrun with tourists, but so what? Get over it, it kind of adds to the atmosphere. Visiting this city is like stepping into the 1600's, yet with all the modern conveniences. If you want to get away from the tourists, just wander off a few blocks and you with the Czechs.
Lovely downtown. Very interesting however crowdy part of Prague. Walk around, have beer in cosy pubs, feel the history.

A wonderful place brilliant atmosphere. We loved the whole area with the astronomical clock and especially two visits to the rooftop terrace of the UPrince Hotel in the square.A special place, lovely food and drinks friendly staff

great space great crowds!. One of the World's great spaces so you have to expect the crowds - go early ( very) to avoid the crowd or late to enjoy the atmosphere. The Astronomical clock does not actually do a lot so do't worry if you can't get near it to see it on the hour - just go on the half hour and you won't have missed a lot!
Great walking area. There are lots of shops, places to eat/drink coffee/beer. We had a great map and found it easy to get around. I loved Prague ... a beautiful city.

Don't go in the middle of the day!. Would be extremely pleasant, but for the crowds. Why do such places always have to have Segway tours and gold or silver-painted painted "live" statues, etc? They all start to look the same!However, the surrounding architecture is outstanding. So try to choose a less-crowded time, eg early morning.

Visit to Prague - City of 100 spires. Prague is well maintained historical city, Public transport and food is inexpensive compared to other european cities. Best way to explore Prague is by a walking tour. Best souvenirs of Prague are Bohemian crystal items.
Winding streets and old world charm. Although reading a map was challenging, Prague's old town is lovely to wander through, with plenty of restaurants, shops, and beautiful buildings.

Totally wonderful. Prague is the most beautiful, fun, musical and affordable city one can go to. And Old Town is the heart of it. We enjoyed the many street performers, the Mucha museum, and outdoor cafes.

Great tourist spot for seeing "old Prague". If you've got some time to spend to see a part of the old Prague, definitely take a walk around the area. It doesn't take long unless you like to really see all the shops and street performers. If you've seen lots of larger European cities with old well maintained tourist spots, then it may feel familiar, but it's Prague, so a quick visit is in order.

commercialized, need to search out gems. Take a walking tour of old town. Tyn Church was fascinating inside. would never have known how to find the hidden door if it weren't for a tour guide. Very commercial - Thai Massage Parlors everywhere with people in costumes giving out flyers. Heard that only 10% of the garnets sold in the tourist shops are real. I bet it was quaint and historic 10 years ago. Now, very cheap looking with souvie shops and Thai massage parlors.
breathtaking for sure!. Sights never get old, beautiful! I love to sit in the main square with wine, enjoying the character of the city.
nice area to stroll. old town is a nice flavor of prague...street performers, souvenir shops, architecture galore...find charles bridge!
Met expectations. A lively and interesting place for all. Horse and cart rides can be taken from here. The clock tower 'performs' on the hour, every hour so make sure you're watching.
Marvellous Hotel. Liked everything, nothing to dislike. Went on walking tour around the castle area, over the Charles Bridge and into the Old Town and river trip.

Beautiful City. We have just returned from a trip to Prague, the old town square was our favourite place to walk through, the astronomical clock and historical building all around the square made it a lovely place to walk through or sit and soak up the atmosphere.

BREATHTAKING. The pictures do it no justice. The old square is just beautiful. The architecture is amazing, and each corner brings new surprises. It is like a fairy tale. The time flies just walking about looking and finding new things to look at. Each building is beautiful. Some review i read before going, were about all the tourists getting in your way, but when you are there, it is different. There is a lovely relaxed atmosphere, and just listening to the different languages is enduring. Everyone is there for the same reason, to enjoy this beautiful city. It really is a city of peace. It really is a city that everyone should visit, everyone is friendly, the shops are brilliant, and the transport is perfect and on time.

Simply Beautiful. Tthe history of Prague is encapsulated in this Old Town. The beautiful architecture and the way the buildings have been preserved is to be applauded. It was virtually untouched by WWII and such a contrast to other cities in Europe in that regard.

Old Town beauty. The architecture is beautiful and the streets are clean and there are many interesting sights to see. The tourist crowds are overwhelming, but we managed to see everything we were interested in seeing. It was a delight to walk around the streets and watch all sorts of people. Shop owners were friendly and helpful.
A most intriguing place. Amazing old buildings and unique feel to this area. Walk about and absorb the feel of this historic part of the city.

First time visit and won't be the last!. Old Town is my favorite attraction in Prague hands down. It's everything I expected: countless souvenir shops, overpriced cafes and restaurants, host of street entertainers, extremely crowded, and narrow and winding alleys. It is also a picturesque place on a clear, sunny day where you can see for miles with superb 360-degree view of the city from the Vez Tower, breathtaking cathedrals and stunning edifices. In short, Old Town is a fantastic place to shop, eat, drink, relax, picture op and people watch, then shop, eat and drink some more before heading back to the hotel. Lots of goods and good memories to bring back home!
So enjoyed Old Town. Old Town was so beautfiul. We saw it during the day and at night. A definite must to visit when you are in Prague

Beautiful Setting -- Out of a Movie. Old Town Square is my favorite area of Prague. The area looks so beautiful and I recall feeling like I was on a movie set (where the buildings are fake). It turned into a more fascinating area at night with the lights from the surrounding churches beaming up to their towers.

Go back in time to the 15th century and experience the experience of the city from this period today.. Kosher eaters: Jewish Quarter closed on Saturday and public holidays.Two kosher restaurants in King Solomon Dunitz and very expensive and not justify the high price.There pankrac Mall Metro station which has a huge supermarket and relatively expensive.

Wanted to stay for awhile. There was so much activity and so many shops, cafes, things to see and do. I loved the festive atmosphere and it was a fantastic place to sit, have a beer and some great food, and watch all the people enjoying the square
It's a must see. We ate at several restaurants just to enjoy the atmosphere, stare are the buildings and people watch.

Lived there for years. There's lots to see and do in old town. Foreigners seem to like the James Joyce Pub. I'd go to the little bar downstairs of the JJ for a more authentic experience. Watch your wallet. Lots of gypsies in old town

Old Town. It's a terrific place, well worth visiting. We are pretty fit and walked all the way from the Hotel Julian to here. Interesting church, fantastic graveyard with lots of famous folks buried, not to mention the charming little one for the nuns just to the left of the church. Nice little museum, and a great restaurant back of the church (not the little snack area in front) where we sat under the trees and enjoyed grilled salmon and salad. Yum. Walked all along the walls. Absolutely fantastic.

Old Town: Pretty but a bit Crowded. Old Town Square is large and pretty to look at. The Tyn church steeples, the large open square and Astronomical Clock make for a must-see when visiting Prague. But during our July visit it was extremely crowded with clock watchers, more crowded than the Charles Bridge at mid day. The swarms of tourists packed shoulder to shoulder made us just want to leave after the clock struck 12! But we were at the mercy of those around us to start thinning out. Not to discourage anyone, just be aware it isn't a spot for quiet or romance when the clock strikes.
Must see!. Get there in time to see the clock. There's a Starbucks nearby for wifi. Go down all the little streets for a better deal on souvenirs.

Lots to see. Old Town Lies on the right bank of Vltava River. It consists of net of small streets and includes also Střelecký Ostrov, an island in Vltava River. It became part of Prague on February 12, 1784This part of the city is often crowded, and prices are higher here but with so much history around, it is a must see for every visitor of Prague. Many monuments are located along Královská Cesta (King's Route) leading from Prašná Brána through Celetná Street, Staroměstské Náměstí (Old Town Square), Karlův Most (Charles Bridge) all the way to Pražský Hrad (Prague Castle).View from the Old Town Square clock tower is also very nice. Admission costs 100.00 CZK

Amazing Architecture. Prague was fortunate to escape most bombing during WWII. As a result, it has one architectural wonder next to another. Be sure to go into the Municipal Building and go down into the basement. It is an art deco paradise! There is also a very good Czech restaurant in the basement which has beautiful and HUGE stained glass windows, so it doesn't feel basement-like at all. Wonderful atmosphere, good service and a gigantic space, so you are not likely to have to wait long even if it is busy.

Interesting architecture and history. Wonderful architectural sites, and agree that there does seem to be an abundance of shopping options and kiosks. I've been there twice, last December and again recently. The tourist attraction is multiplied during the Christmas season adding an additional excitement, and crowd.

Unline Any Other Square. Old Town Square is so much more interesting than the more widely known Wenceslas Square which is more oblong boulevard. It is chock full of live events and you have the feeling that the celebration goes on all night. It is beautiful to look at, full of overpriced restaurants (so we were advised to go down narrower streets to look for food), famous churches and glorious architecture. If for no other reason than to people watch, this is the place to do it. But do it in some month other than August when it is difficult to avoid elbow to elbow crowds.
Just walk around. I downloaded a map and just walked around the main areas and little streets. Stop at a pastry shop, take your time and savor this area!

Loved Prague. The square is lovely, center of everything, great restaurants all around. We stayed in the square (basically) and had a view of square from our room. All important landmarks are within walking distance

Old Town. Many shops. Wonderful old buildings and interesting people to photograph. Bumped into the British actor Jason Isaacs (Lucius Malfoy in Potter movies). Street performers of all nationalities and skills. from bagpiper in kilts to steel drummers. Even a one-man band.) Well worth the trip just to people watch. One thing about the Czech Republic: people who might have been left behind as capitalism flourishes are now employed cleaning public restrooms. They also collect 50 cents Euro. There aren't any free bathrooms.

Old Prague. Fabulous old city. The architecture is amazing. Walk around through the winding off the path streets and find some interesting restaurants and pubs. Try to visit the church just off the square, and the Communism Museum is awesome.

Picture Peffect. Lovely old town, very nice old building to look at and take pictures of. Very busy with tourists and shops, bars, cafes, restaurants. But you would expect this as a major tourist attraction. Street performs in the square in the evenings.

Beautiful, but seedy.... Don't get me wrong, the Old Town is beautiful, the most amazing buildings and architecture, but once 11 o clock kicks in, we noticed a lot of people (including ourselves) being approached by dealers and pimps. Disappointing to see in such a fantastic city. Also you are constantly competing for space with other tourists in the Old Town. Certainly go visit and for a stroll, but I would personally recommend the Mala Strana or Little Quarter for accommodation. It has as many great restaurants and pubs, but less people and seediness.

great cheap food. like all old towns they are more interesting and have more character. try eating at the little stalls as they have cheap and great food if you dont mind standing up. watch out for pick pocketers as you can see them checking their next victims. wander down all the little alleys as there is alot of interesting shops away from the main square.
Superb. Really brilliant - we went at the right time, it was busy but I think that in the summer months it must be VERY busy

Don't Miss. This is old Prague and a perfect place for walking and shopping and snacking as you take in the charm of this wonderful old city. The only sad note is the appalling amount of graffiti to be found throughout the area.

Some very interesting history, unfortunately hidden underneath a layer of tourist trap. I do like the opportunity to interact with history! And there is plenty of it in Prague. I got completely DONE with one shop after another selling the same trinkets as the last shop. After my 2nd day here, I did not even enter another one. That is fine, obviously, for many tourists [must be - SOMEONE'S buying up a lot of landfill], but that leaves people like myself pretty much out of the picture in terms of making money off of my footprint. Not a problem! It just means I end up spending less than I otherwise might be inclined and might have a much greater spending capacity for.I don't feel I have to settle for a US Flag pin or a plaster Eiffel Tower that was made in China [as an example, an illustration of what makes me turn around and immediately head out of most shops].
Wonderful architecture. Most of the buildings are photogenic and it's easy to wander around without getting lost and seems quite safe if you use common sense.

Old Town Square Prague. Old Town Square is the first call for 99% of tourists and even your bored teen kids won't be disappointed as you stand looking up at the awe inspiring Gothic splendour. Make sure you are there as the hour strikes to see the incredible Prague Astronomical Clock - built in 1410 - on the Old Town Hall. You will be astonished to see actual animatronic figures appear! Your bored teens - raised on 3D video games - maybe slightly less 'whelmed' than you, but do explain the clock was built 600 years ago (before Nintendo existed) and before they slope off to Starbucks - less than 50 metres away across Old Town Square - do attempt to regale them with the legend of the master clock maker, Master Hanuš who created a wonder of its day:Back in 1410 the City Councillors were so thrilled with their astonishing astronomical clock that, in an act of somewhat disturbing gratitude towards its creator, decided to poke his eyes out, rendering the perplexed and, I imagine, startled Master Hanuš completely blind. Their reason was fear that Hanuš would build an even better clock for another European city. Not overly pleased with his newly acquired 'visually challenged' status - Hanuš was led, under cover of darkness, by a friend to the clock, where he removed a secret brick. Reaching inside he disabled the clock mechanism for the next 500 years... Your bored teen kids may now mutter the word, 'cool' or 'whatever', before heading off for a much needed Starbucks Macchiato. The more prosaic reality of the clock story is that it was built by Mikulas of Kadan (in 1410) assisted by astronomer and Charles University professor, Jan Sindel. The clock never really worked that successfully and eventually ground to a halt for several centuries. In 1865 it was restored and given a new mechanism and has worked ever since. Some of the animatronic figures on the clock were damaged by the German army in the second world war and have been replaced.  Astronomical Clock ticked-off the 'to do' list, it maybe time to get something to eat: I'm not a big fan of any of the restaurants on Old Town Square, as the owners don't need repeat business and food is distinctly average and over-priced. The restaurants want to feed you and free the table for their next customer as fast as possible. I suggest heading to smaller restaurants up one of the many side streets, and if you see Czech people eating in there it's probably good!

Great walking tour. The architecture is not to be missed. Easy to maneuver except the cobblestone streets wear on your feet by the end of the day. Stop at the outdoor vendors and get the just cooked potato chips on a stick. Nothing like this in the USA! Great window shopping, too.
Great great great. It is the best old town i have ever seen!it is fantastic and dont miss it . Be in this place at the weekend to visit some small shop and eat diffrent things.
Great to Walk Around In. The crowds, even at the beginning of October, were terrible, especially during the weekend. This was especially true on the Charles Bridge and on the Old Town Square
Nice. Nice and cosy place to walk around, enjoying the old architecture of Prague. Take place on one of the sitting banks you can find all around you.

Astronomical Clock. Must visit includes the Astronomical Clock and Old Town Square at night - just magical. Plus what could be better than eating at a local Czech restaurant whilst listening to the buskers.
Historic area for shopping and eating. A must see for shopping and eating. This area also leads you to the famous and beautiful Charles Bridge. Make sure you visit during the day and again at night.

The best of Prague. On our second day in Prague we took a tour which took us to many historic places but the Old town square was by far the best. The buildings were well maintained showing the best. The clock tower and the cathedral and many to other things to see. The place is festive with so many shops and restaurants around. There were stalls selling all sorts of food. Tour guides were out in force giving waking tours, sagway tours or even on horse carriage. It was fun waking around that we had to come again.
Awesome prague.. One of the best place to visit. Everything is beautiful....walking there is the most beautiful thing..Best time to go is September....street food amazing..

Old town. Old town is part of Prague in the Czech Republic, it has so much beauty, the Churches are beautiful especially St , Nicolas and Our Lady of Victory which is The infant of Prague church. old town also has many shops and great restaurants with Czech cuisine. I love Prague for its old time beauty that was not destroyed by Hitler.
Wonderful. Packed with amazing sights, but very crowded. If you come before 9 am the shops are still closed and there are just a few tourists around.
Beautiful area to wander around. the old town square is very beautiful and mysterious. definitely a place to get lost with a lover since it is very romantic. it is a must!

Lovely. Really nice old town, beautiful buildings, quaint little shops and amazing bridge all within walking distance. We went for the Christmas Markets, wonderful stalls selling hot spicy drinks and all sorts of different gifts. Great atmosphere too, with carol singing and all festive things to do. The clock is also amazing, fabulous views from the top! All in all, a great place to visit for a long weekend trip.

Prague is the most unexpected, unmissable delight in Europe!. There are not enough superlatives to convey the magic and beauty of Prague. The welcoming kindness of its people (and English is easily understood even if not easily spoken but do yourself and the rest of the world a favor and don't be the ugly American: LEARN A LITTLE CZECH and show some RESPECT!!!), the easy walkability of the town, the profound gravity of the Jewish Quarter, the astonishing food and views... and our all-time favorite place to stay at The Golden Well and the unforgettable hospitality of Simon at the front desk and Oxzana at the restaurant -- Prague is the gem we never expected to find but to which we so fervently hope to return. And DO take the train as we did from Salzburg! It's so important to see the transition from modernized Austria thru the post-Communist countryside outside Prague to fully grasp and appreciate the transformative power of the Czech "spring." Every Czech is a hero, and the beauty and vitality of their glorious country is true testimony to that.

Old Town Prague. We loved Old Town esp the astronomical clock. The architecture and statues are stunning. It is right on the transit lines. The restaurants great. We shopped at the Chrystal shop across from the clock. It was at least 1 block long. So much Chrystal it was really difficult to choose. Beware people with umbrellas in the rain as they pop them up in front of you so all you get to see is an umbrella. It is very crowded with tourists

The best place in Prague. This is where you'll want to spend your time. It can be touristy, but try to get there in the early morning to beat the crowds and pushy vendors, or wander around in the evening when all the buildings are beautifully lit up and you can enjoy the outdoor cafe scene.

Only one drawback... too many tourists around. Like an open air museum, medieval times and later historical times all blend in a superb harmony, good policy on keeping the centre low in traffic too. One should take time to invest in a proper guidebook on the centre, it's worth it. Also, strolling the centre during evening times is great, because not too many people around then

Must go place. I've been to Prague twice in different situations - couple and friends. Old Town is simply fantastic and where everything in Prague happens. Nice old buildings and bridges that must be seen.

Old Town. Enchanting and a wonderful place to set, have coffee, wine, and people watch. The Tower was breath-taking but not for those who have a fear of heights!!Lots of entertainment in the square but watch your pockets!!

Prague Transit System targets tourists. If you look or act like a tourist, the transit police will target you..even if you have the right ticket. Common violations they cite..wrong fare, ticket not punched, ticket invalid. You can't fight it, you are always wrong. The fine ranges from U.S. $20 to $80. My daughter and I had full fare tickets to airport..transit police cited some excuse in broken English and fined us $80 each. Either missed the fight or pay up.My friend's husband who often wears a baseball cap was an easy target. Fined 3 times on different days until he stopped wearing the cap. Lots of complaints on websites about this problem.

a lovely old square.. A lovely old square. Lots going on. The buildings were amazing. you can get horse carriage rides from this square. also a small train takes you around the main sites of the city. a real must when you visit Prague
Old ages revival. a huge and irregular space surrounded by some very old buildings as well as some neweer ones, all showwing beautiful achitecture and decoration
amazing place..... Something for everyone, architecture takes your breath away, the astrological clock is stunning, great shops and restaurants, but just fabulous!!!
Good value. Better value for money, lots to see and a little quieter than the new town. Cafe's are less crowded and the streets also less crowded.

Prague at it's best. Old Town was our favorite area of Prague with the churches, the winding cobble stone streets and the old Town Square. Take one of the many free tours offered from the square or book one on your own. Unless you know Prague's amazing history, it is hard to truly appreciate this city beyond the beautiful architecture. Abundant amount of restaurants, cafes and shops but also very crowded. Be sure to go up the tower of the city hall (there is an elevator) to get amazing views of the city.
Amazing architecture. The old town of Praha is beautiful. Many many beautiful buildings, bridges and random little hidden things that are worth exploring.

Definitely worth a stop. There isn't much to do, but it is definitely worth walking through Old Town Square. The astronomical clock and church are both beautiful and are must sees on even a short trip is Prague.

In love with Prague. My husband and I visited Prague last month. From the US we started our trip with 7 days in Vienna - quite a beautiful city. Then we took the train to Salzburg where we spent 3 days - also lovely place where we enjoyed our stay and loved the tours we took there in spite of the rain. They were tours of the Lake and Mountains and the Sound of Music tour - both very scenic. We took a day tour to Budapest - another beautiful place- and we were happy to have taken the tour although we would have needed at least 3 days to get a better idea of Budapest. But it was worth it. Then we headed for Prague where we spent 3 days. PRAGUE IS SO SO SO BEAUTIFUL. It was our favorite place, so well preserved. It has not been very affected by the war and is a real gem! Compared to Vienna which is beautiful, we felt that Prague had the edge - we fell in love with it. There is so much to see there! The one thing we regret having taken was a dinner cruise - a complete waste of time and money. Otherwise, our other regret was to not have stayed longer in Prague. We also noted that the people are very friendly and friendlier that the Viennese. We stayed at "Ma Maison" hotel which we recommend (well located, with a fantastic view if you can get a corner room on the higher floors). We then left Prague to go back to Vienna, but on our way we stopped for one night at a little medieval town called Cesky Krumlov (also in the Czech Republic). Cesky Krumlov is such a beautiful place!!! All worth the stop there. So, the highlight of our trip was our stay in Prague! We will probably go back to Prague a must see, so beautiful!
Amazing. Would definitely visit again. Pretty nice place.Tip: go up the tower in the old square. Pretty nice sights from up there
Fantastic Architecture. What I like most about Prague is the way the fantastic architecture has survived the wars in Europe and has been restored. There are some really stunning buildings.
Historic & Beautiful. Beautiful architecture and atmosphere. Very very busy. There was so much to see. You could wander about for hours. Beware of pick pockets. I had my purse stolen.

Eateries galore and much much more!. The old town square is a central square reminiscent of st marks square in Venice, eateries in the form of covered pavement restaurants and cafe's galore. It isalso the place for a visit to current art exhibitions, Dali and Mucha on offer during our visit, and an opportunity for shopping! Follow the lnarrow little street at the side of Starbucks coffee house, and eventually you will reach the market with the most amazing fruit and vegetables, beautifully presented, reasonably priced, huge in size, and delicious to taste! There are also musicians, sometimes acrobats, and a host of other entertainers that pop up in the square from time to time.
Good location to visit. Narrow winding streets and lots of restaurants and bars. Very lively place. Wouldn't want to stay anywhere else.
Old Town. Another lovely part of the city, plenty to see, places to eat etc. Busy at night but a great "buzz". Like any tourist area common sense has to used where to carry wallets etc.
Great short break. Prague old town is vibrant, so much going on, entertainment; places to eat; places to see; really interesting.

View from above. Love it all..architecture...atmosphere etc
Opposite the clock is a hotel with a wonderful roof restaurant with stunning views over the square.

Busy! Busy! Busy!. This square is a hustling and bustling place. So much to experience that it is almost sensory overload. The various booths with local specialties is something to experience. Go from booth to booth and take it all in...and eat the day away with the wonderful foods they offer.
Lots of interesting streets. It's a really enjoyable place to walk around and find lots of little side streets to wander down. Plenty of photo ops and some really nice individual shops.

The first place to go in Prague. When coming into Prague, this is the first place you should visit, no questions asked. The architecture is beautiful (most of Prague is but it's concentrated here,) and the "Adam & Eve" cathedral (you'll know what I'm talking about when you see it) is one of the prettiest buildings I've ever seen, especially at night. The town square is a great place with great atmosphere. Full of tourists, yes, but it has a better vibe than most cities' main square I've noticed. More fun and relaxed. The old town area is nice, the streets are charming with old cobblestone and a medieval feel, and very confusing to navigate! There are some great little places hidden around here, some nice cheap little local spots, and just as many or more overpriced tourist traps. Try asking a local where to go.The only reason I'm giving it a 4 star is because of the general overpriced-ness of the area and the tourist traps, but that's to be expected in any city's main square.Again, there are plenty of nice little places you'd never expect to find, you just have to find them! Or of course, ask someone that lives around here.At night, do expect to be asked if you want drugs or to go to a strip club or disco, but that's expected as well. The touts and dealers aren't pushy though, and it's far from dangerous. Just a polite "no thanks" (or even better, "ne díky") will get them off your back immediately. Don't feel threatened here, Prague is a safe city.I've been here for four months or so total and still come back to Old Town a few times per week.

Fabulous, If rather crowded.. We stayed in Stare Mesto, and it was one of the most beautiful places in the city. Of course prague has a reputation of being a living museum, and even though the museums that you pay to get into are great, you are better off with just walking around the city, for it is best way to see the city, and old town is the very thing that makes this city.

Definately the heart of Prague!. No trip to Prague would be complete without coming here and all roads in the city seem to lead back here when you are wandering around. It does get very very busy at the weekends and during the day! I came here early in the morning and at midnight and it was beautiful. I also came at peak tourist time and it was rammed with people all waiting for the astronomical clock. There are lots of restaurants all providing views of the square. Ofcourse they are over priced but then you get to enjoy this atmosphere. And to be honest, everywhere in Prague near the tourists sites are overpriced. I had a hot chocolate with rum here in one of the restaurants and paid around 140 czk for this...which I think was worth it for the scenery and my own personal enjoyment.The clock...oh jeez everyone goes on about it! I actually really liked it! Its low key, its fun, its a beautiful clock and I probably saw it about 3 times on the hour...just don't expect much and you won't be dissappointed. Beware the Prague Ham Scam!!! There are certain wooden street stalls around the square and Old Town selling 'traditional street food' at extortionate rip off prices. I saw numerous tourists being charged 40 euros plus in czech currency for a plate of fatty ham and a bowl of potatoes. The prices listed seem reasonable initially but they are per 100g. You end up paying 20 euros jus for a bowl of potoatoes. It nearly happened to us, however, I refused to pay as the price did not seem right. However, numerous tourists looked very confused and just pulled out more money. They rely on the confusion and the fact that it all happens so quickly and perhaps tourists are not so familiar with the currency. And this feeling that once you have ordered it you have to pay for it. I said No and walked away and they were pissed but its a massive scam. Lots of other people were walking away thinking what just happened. Yes you paid 40 euros plus for a plastic plate of cheap food!!! Just be careful and do not buy it. Three people can eat in a sit down restaurant for the same price. If you are desperate to try 'Prague Ham' which essentially is normal ham inflated for tourists...go to a restaurant where you will have a fixed price. If you want to buy food on the street, the Tredlniks are great at 40 czk each and are these circular pastries. Everywhere sells them. The hots dogs also are cheap too. There is also gelato everywhere which is delicious.

Untouched history. This square offers everything(2 churches, a beautiful clock tower, great street shows, and some good resturants).It is alive night and day. You can't come to Prague and miss this place. 8.5/10

My favourite town!. In my opinion Prague is the most intimate, nice town in Europe. Old town square is a absolute must during all my visits to this town. Being a regular visitor to Prague since 1985 I've seen the beauty grow around all the city. The visitors must walk out of the "tourist route" and visit all the nice areas around in the city. All the nice "back yard" restaurants, small parks, and narrow streets.I'm impressed by the government how they have used all this money to reconstruct and shine up the city. If you haven't been in Prague, you should try it soon.
Clock tower. The Stare Mesto is interesting. If you get out early in the morning you will miss the horrible crowds. Go to the clock tower early, too. Go to the top for great photo opportunities.
Atmosphere!!. Great city! Lots of historical sites. Easy to get around. Many good restaurants with reasonable prices. Good guiding services. I'm sure I will return.

Super !!. Whenever you are in Prague, the old town is a MUST. It is the place where tourists mingle with locals and have a really good time. Many restaurants, pubs, bars and museums are situated. It is great to be there by day and by night. So please, take my word..you will enjoy it for sure. One IMPORTANT TIP....Do not leave your wallet in your back pocket... Better safe than sorry ! It is just like any big city in the world.

Good place with buildings with different architecture style!. The fact that its called Old Town square it doesnt mean that it is bad (not place to visit). To me the square is awesome considering its surrounded by buildings with different architecture style with different time era. The best of all is the fact that one tower of the old church is longer than other for about 1m. Check it yourself (then ask the native) and leave your comment down why is like that from your point of view?

Amazing during the day and at night. The buildings around are so amazing you even forget the crowds of tourists. You can't really blame other people for wanting to enjoy this incredibly special place. Maybe the best moment to enjoy it is early in the morning when everyone else is having breakfast.

Great place to check out but would not stay here. The atmosphere in Old Town was great. I loved the architecture and the small cobblestone streets. There were many good restaurants and cafes, although some were more expensive than those located in the less touristy areas. There were also many stores but most seemed to sell the same souvenirs that looked a little cheap. Overall, this is a very busy but fun part of Prague to visit but I wouldn't want to stay here and deal with the crowds every time I left my hotel room.

perfection!. the powder tower the Astronomical clock and almost every building is amazing! we had a free tour that started from the astronomical clock then to the Jewish quarter and ended with na prikope street..the guide explains a lot about the history of the country and a lot of facts about random buildings,which was pretty cool. i recommend touring with a guide for the first 3 hours and then wonder around and enjoy getting lost in the small streets..

Outstanding experience that exceeds expectations. Wonderful European city with plenty to discover. Endless variety of historical sites, restaurants and baskers. The experience changes in the evening and the play of neon lights on ancient edifices is startling and breathtaking.Bring along a guidebook or Google translator. Or seek help from the tourist office, but not the ubiquitous police officers who seem offended that they should provide helpful direction to lost tourists.
Prague is just beautiful. What a place. So many things to do . Lots of resturants, street performance, musics, etc. Wonderful place to visit.
I love Prague. Prague especially the Old town was one of the nicest place I've been to. Very romantic and charming. This is one city not to be missed in your itinerary.
nice square. I recomend to vist the clock in old tow square, and also Paladium shopping centre, is great for shoping
Tick tock. We enjoyed everything, especially the astronomical clock located there!!! It's a delightful area to sit, have a drink & people watch!!

City I would visit if I hadn't been to Rome. The Charles Bridge, the Clock in the Old Town Center, the Churches through out the City. St. Agnes Convent in the Jewish Quarter and everything about the City was great. Public transportation was easy to use. All day pass about $5.00 and if over 60 then half

Beautiful. Architecturally beautiful but so, so busy at all hours of the day and night! We went up the tower at night (they have a lift, thankfully) and the views were amazing. The restaurants were overpriced but I guess you are paying for being in the square - go one street back and they are cheaper, would recommend Pizzeria Giovanni which was excellent. Always full of musicians/photographers/film crews and those odd "statue people" (never understood those?). Cant imagine you could go to Prague and avoid this place!

One of the most beautiful capital town in Europe. Evertything is clean,renovated and viewe from the Carols Bridge is great.The buildings most from the 19 th century are in secesion style.The best one is cultural music center.

The Best place to be in Prague. The Old Town is the cultural heart of Prague really. It has all the best buildings, the best Architecture, famous houses, loads of cafes/Bars with lots of outdoor seating and is the best part of a great city.

Nice vibe amazing buildings. Very cool place to see and have a beer, latte or hot chocolate. The Astronomical Clock is beautiful...the architecture surrounding the square is (as is all of Prague) great!
Centre of town. What place so full of life. Very busy but with so many places to visit within it. start your tours from there

Old world charm. This place is just a 5 to 10 minutes walking distance from the Charles Bridge. You have beautifully carved buildings and churches around the square and also the famous Astronomical Clock which this place is known for

History, Architecture - Amazing Center of Beauty!. We chose to stay in an Old Town hotel, even though it was pricier than those in the outskirts of the city, because we wanted to soak in the atmosphere of this historical area and I'm so glad we did. Prague is an amazing place and Old Town is absolutely amazing!! I could easily imagine the middle ages and other times throughout history as I walked through the winding, narrow streets and looked at different styles of buildings. Cobblestone streets, statues, narrow alleys, shops, restaurants - you could easily spend an entire vacation just within these few blocks without running out of things to see and do! I can't wait to go back and spend more time in Prague as I feel like I've just scratched the surface on this amazing center of beauty!
Very Quaint. This reminds you of the quintessential European town. Lots of things to see, places to eat and the hub for travel to other city locations.

The place to stay.. We stayed in Old town and preferred it. Rich in history and architecture, walking around this area is one surprise after another. All of the narrow alleys, shops, restaurants and cafes to tempt us. Get lost in Old Town!
Stay here.. We stayed right in Old Town, and walked everywhere. Lots to do and see. This is the place to be in Prague.

Great place to hang out and watch people.. Best beer in Europe and there are cafes around the town center where you can grab a table to watch buskers/street performers, as well as other tourists. Strike up a conversation with those sitting at the next table and you're off to a great time.

Walking in history. Compact and almost traffic free. There are traffic indicators as to where the various sites are.
Sometimes there are to many tourist wanting the same thing around.

So chilled. We loved being here. The architecture, the ambiance, the chill out chances to sit and have a cold beer. Fantastic. The area is relaxed and very safe.The astronomical clock and the views from the Old Town Hall Tower all add up to making this area a must see during your visit to the excellent City of Prague. We really enjoyed it!!
A picture of the past. Walking the streets and viewing the buildings from the 12th century on gives a real picture of what life was like. Wonderful that it has been preserved.
Old world yet fun!. easy to navigate, many restaurants and great sights. Fun in the evening. Catch the astronomical clock on the hour.

Beautiful City, Amazing History. There's nothing to dislike. Beautiful buildings, and if you have the right guide you learn a lot about our own Royal Families connections. The locals seem to really care about their city and it is so clean.

A must on any visit to Prague. This was our second trip to Prague and we still chose to return to this square every day. It is especially lovely in the morning before the crowds grow, but it is pleasant just to sit in the square, have a drink and watch the world go by. Very interesting architecture. You can choose a different street each day and explore a different nook of the city.

Beautiful!. Prague's old town is beautiful! So colorful and cozy, all the attractions are within walking distance and there's always something to be amazed, even while walking between one place to another.
Great Architecture. We enjoyed walking the narrow winding streets and seeing the variety of architectural styles. The entire area is very picturesque.

Unbelievable. This city just continues to amaze with every corner you turn.
The Old Town is a myriad of beautiful old buildings that seem to go on forever

very well preserved. The old town in Prague was a delight. The buildings survived the war, are very well preserved and kept in very good condition. It was a pleasure to walk round and I enjoyed my trip to Prague more than I thought I would. Do a little internet research before you go and decide what you want to see. There are some excellent guided tours available and your hotel will help you with this. Lovely City.
Beautiful. Avoid the crowds if you can by visiting early or later in the evening. Very lively, and touristy as to be expected.
A beutiful town and a nice walk. + interesting, beutiful houses+ small and easy to walk, very clean+ rich history- a lot of drunken teens in the night- very turistic

Fairy-tale beautiful. Old Town is a wonderful destination within Prague. It's definitely the most touristy part of the city, but with the exquisite Old World charm that is unique, it's a must-visit when in Prague.

Old ? A bit too comercial. guess this part of town is an attraction to all visitors , but we found it to be a bit over crowded in New High end Brand Shopswhich is ok, But all this modern takes away from charm of old town historical area - which by lookig up at the architecture one will see was an amazing area even in old times without cartier, omega & hugo boss came to prague..
OLd History. Place where you can find history alive. Amazing through day, night and every season. It is pretty close everywhere. Sometimes it is just to much packed with tourist

Definitely worth a visit. The astronomical clock was amazing . Knowing about its history would help to appreciate it more. The bell tower gives you a great view of Prague . Must visit . Pram are allowed only till the third floor after that you can carry your baby and there is a lift available. Local cuisine available in abundance . Definitely worth a visit .

Overwhelmed by number of sights (and tourists). Far too many beautiful and characterful buildings to take in everything completely, totally overwhelming. The incessant crocodiles of tourists lead by umbrella-toting tourists are also overwhelming unforunately meaning that you are constantly in a scrum which rather spoils it all.Easy to get lost; the second most common sight after the buildings is a tourist trying to decipher a map with miniscule writing!

Well Worth It, But Crowded. The Stare Mesto is filled with interesting sights, quaint little side streets, magnificent baroque churches -- and crowds of tourists. One sometimes feels like it's a theme park rather than a real town. Nevertheless, not to be missed.

Crowded and popular with all.. The whole area is extremely crowded and popular with the young. The Souvenie rshops are all here with Czech Bohemian glass chandeliers and jewelry. First floor Square #1 we saw for the first time the Czech artist MUCHA, of the Belle Epoque , also some interesting fascimiles of Dali.
Stpped in the time. Prague is a beautiful city, untouched by the wars, so everything is intact. medieval style. the streets are with stone bricks and all the buildings are very old
Nice just walking around. But at some point you will get lost, but you will find your way again, though maybe not the shortest way, then just enjoy the atmosphere
Full of History. This was our favourite part of Prague. Everywhere you looked there was amazing architecture, historical buildings and busy cafes and bars. Definately a true representation of Prague.

Delightful and colourful place....feels like a fair all time. Most famous among Prague sights, the Old Town Square is a indeed a fun place to visit. Lined with medieval buildings around the square, it has the Opera, Tyn Church and Astronomical clock as its main attractions. The center of the square is filled with small souvenir shops and snack stalls. In winter dont miss to taste hot bread rolls and hot wine. Do take a walk behind the Tyn church along old cobbled streets and you land surprisingly in smaller squares which sell unique wooden witches which one buys to ward off evil spirits. Also the hourly event at the Astronomical clock is must see. Overall a delightful place........
